Perhaps the same rule is bidirectional (it would make sense - aquatic life being quite sensitive to temperature).', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531140618000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'117995670', u'id': u'118010159', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'It's now a standard item - you can just buy them, and new builds really should have them as standard: a lot of heat is wasted down drains. https://www.zypho.eu/products/zypho-standard/http://shower-save.com/products.htmlYou can also make your own for very little money indeed, but it's quite tricky to get good efficiency.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531140433000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'117999929', u'id': u'118009954', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobDee', u'text': u'I prefer them rare.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531140009000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3232913', u'in_reply_to': u'117977527', u'id': u'118009476', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CanalChris', u'text': u'A strand is a beach, so called because when the tide goes out your ship/boat is stranded on dry land, or at least shallow water. You can then effect any repairs needed below the waterline (re-planking, caulking etc) as well as load/unload supplies and cargo without needing a proper dock or quay. You had to time it right to beat the returning tide though!In London, The Strand was the original shoreline of the Thames used for this purpose, as described by other posters above.One reference that comes to mind is a delightful song called 'Yarmouth Town' which refers to 'the tavern by the strand'. So, not the one in London.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531139919000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'when the tide goes out your ship boat is stranded on dry land or at least shallow water', u'effect': u'so called'}], u'author_id': u'12823630', u'in_reply_to': u'117992943', u'id': u'118009363', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Higham', u'text': u'Please make clear it would only be fossil fuel-free heat if the electricity used to power the heat pumps is generated without fossil fuels. The idea is a good one and would be worthwhile even with the electricity grid at current levels of carbon intensity but not fossil fuel-free.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531139625000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11746164', u'id': u'118009044', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'"I've always wondered why it isn't used more on new builds." At the moment it comes down to simple economics and the fact that gas is very cheap. Even a very efficient GSHP will have a CoP of 4 at best so for every one unit of electricity input you will get 4 units of heat out. Gas however is better than a quarter of the price of electricity - on my own tariff gas is 3.379p per KWh whilst electricity is 15.065p per KWh making electricity 4.45 times more expensive. The capital costs of installing a GSHP are probably 15 to 20 times more even on new build. Of course if you are not on a gas main then a heat pump will beat any other option on cost.In the Netherlands new build gas heating is now banned which is quite probably the only way to get heat pumps into the UK system en masse.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531139234000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100526028', u'in_reply_to': u'117983202', u'id': u'118008617', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathonFields', u'text': u'The cost is not relevant: it is imperative to stop all green-house-gas emissions today.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531138152000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4634960', u'in_reply_to': u'117993608', u'id': u'118007302', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Martin Gutkowski', u'text': u'Because with a heat pump you get more heat output than power input. Often in excess of 3x. Search "coefficient of performance" for more info.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531138130000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13616291', u'in_reply_to': u'118006979', u'id': u'118007275', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathonFields', u'text': u'I don't know why you say that. Surely everyone understands how a fridge works, which is pumping heat from inside the fridge to the radiator outside of the fridge, and a heat-pump does the same, in much the same way.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531137899000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4634960', u'in_reply_to': u'118004221', u'id': u'118006979', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gramercy', u'text': u'BQSTART
"...a source of fossil fuel-free heat."
BQEND
Perhaps destabilizing the riverbeds and collapsing the city...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531137601000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2640151', u'id': u'118006583', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'Mathematics is not on your side with that one. Hydro electric power is a simple calculation:- Power (watts) = head (metres) x flow (litres/sec) x acceleration due to gravity (9.81m/sec/sec) x operating efficiency (typically 65% water to electricity).Low head water power gives low power unless you have staggeringly large quantities of flow which UK rivers do not have. The industrial revolution used extremely little power from low head water compared to today's consumption levels.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531137576000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'gravity', u'effect': u'acceleration'}], u'author_id': u'100526028', u'in_reply_to': u'117994997', u'id': u'118006554', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'"the lack of regen braking is easily fixed with a small battery on each train- that could be used to allow for acceleration from the station - it would also allow the live track to be diverted away from passengers when it reached the station."
Plus pretty massive rewiring and (I suspect) a major redesign of the motors. but that misses a major problem - tube trains are VERY space-restricted beasts, and the use of train-forced ventilation means they already fill the tunnel cross section pretty completely (it's one of the reasons that fitting aircon hasn't got far).
So no, I think realistically, it's new rolling stock.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531136921000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'118005426', u'id': u'118005682', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'no wonder the heat builds up to that which would illegal to transport cattle.
the lack of regen braking is easily fixed with a small battery on each train- that could be used to allow for acceleration from the station - it would also allow the live track to be diverted away from passengers when it reached the station.
The most economic route to combined h&p is for the heat to go to an industrial area- Slough trading estate had its own power station and the factories had steam outlets [i worked in a sugar processing plant in my student years - horrid and sticky- and I cleaned tanks with steam that could kill]. btw Slough actually had its own water company- both of which were owned I think by the council until privatisation.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531136689000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'118002045', u'id': u'118005426', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Martin Gutkowski', u'text': u'Heat pumps: The nearest thing to witchcraft in engineering (and almost impossible to explain to the layman...)', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531135701000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13616291', u'id': u'118004221', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'"one large swimming-pool's worth. "
I make it about 13 Olympic sized pools. (50mx10x1.5m average depth). Bit of a challenge to fit into the foundations of a building.
And, of course, the hotter you go, the more of a losses issue you have.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531135477000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'118003448', u'id': u'118003936', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'Oh, and you've got mail, btw.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531135245000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'118003317', u'id': u'118003671', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'Hmmm....
Not viable, assuming we need to keep the temperature differentials reasonable.
Even were all other things equal, you'd not now be allowed to build a new Battersea Power station, gas fired, nuclear, biomass or waste fired. Not because of atmospheric pollution, but simply because you'd not be allowed to dump that much heat into the Thames.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531135183000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"simply you 'd not be allowed to dump that much heat into the thames", u'effect': u'not because of atmospheric pollution but'}], u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'117997473', u'id': u'118003608', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'Which is a tank 15x15x45m. Large but not crazy for building of that size - one large swimming-pool's worth. And you could halve the size by storing at 80C. How much of the 2MW comes from the people and computers and coffee machines in there? Most offices have surprisingly small actual 'extra' heating requirements because they have so much heat generation inside already. Mostly they have a large cooling requirement. But I guess tall thin buildings have high losses.
Here's a few buildings that have annual heat-storage in a very large water tank: http://www.jenni.ch/bauprojekte-jenni.html', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531135052000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they have so much heat generation inside already', u'effect': u'most offices have surprisingly small actual requirements'}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'117996390', u'id': u'118003448', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'Unless you're willing to do some drilling and plumbing then I suggest a 'slim Jim' -(my secondary source) - a faff to unship and not to be done single handed but very efficient unless you're off somewhere.I know a guy who swears he made one using 30m of plastic hose he strung in loops under his stationary barge.My boat had a pumped saltwater WSHP fitted with motor heat recovery (I bought from a guy in Norway) and it was already configured for colder climes.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531135041000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'118000161', u'id': u'118003434', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'It becomes weighted average issue.
Turbine condensors are normally a "counterflow" type - that is the cooling water and steam/condensate flow in opposite directions, so that you maintain a reasonably good dT along the length.
All you'd do is segregate off the very hottest end to feed your district heating system, and the lower end to dump to ambient.
So yes, some impact - but nothing like what you'd expect.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531134941000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'117998056', u'id': u'118003317', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AuntyLiz', u'text': u'And now they are sewage free they'd look nice.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531134812000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100149647', u'id': u'118003176', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'konallis', u'text': u'At least some were covered in the 18th century, because they were basically open sewers and were regularly blocked with rubbish from the streets.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531134757000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they were basically open sewers and were regularly blocked with rubbish from the streets', u'effect': u'at least some were covered in the 18th century'}], u'author_id': u'13835343', u'in_reply_to': u'117998133', u'id': u'118003107', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'Maybe the Guardian could get a more numerate reporter?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531134702000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'117999365', u'id': u'118003042', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'" the costs extremely high and ultimately no private investment to get the scheme going"
That's where this gets interesting. When I did the numbers for the original discussion about Bristol, two years ago, I was looking for a comparator scheme to get some idea what running pipes of similar size a similar distance would cost. I found a water scheme in Northern Ireland. 
http://www.waterprojectsonline.com/case_studies/2015/NIW_Castor_Bay_to_Belfast_Main_2015.pdf 
- £14M (in 2014) for 30km of twin 500mm+ pipes laid in concrete trenching. As I said at the time, you could double that up for insulation and heve a very safe estimate.
The issue isn't the changes at the nuclear station - it's the distribution network in town.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531134647000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'118000906', u'id': u'118002979', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'The only affect on the rivers will be a drop in temperature. How much wildlife is living in tunneled rivers under London (presumably some fish/invertebrates?), and how sensitive is it to temperature?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531134171000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'117995865', u'id': u'118002465', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'It's not just the waste heat from the motors, Jules- remember most of the rolling stock doesn't use anything as sophisticated as regenerative braking, so reptyy much all the motor output also ends up as waste heat.
And there aren't really ventilation shafts per se - air is forced up through the stations.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531133783000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'118001251', u'id': u'118002045', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LarryJayCee', u'text': u'London Underground already have to continuously pump water out of the Tube network to prevent it flooding.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531133119000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4049805', u'in_reply_to': u'117983162', u'id': u'118001383', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'electric motors on tubes are pretty efficient but 25% of all that electrical energy is being dumped as heat- and I guess simply forcing the air around a tight fitting tube is going to create friction [and for other readers, hold the end of bike pump with your finger, pump away and feel the heat]... and more heat.
So the ventilation shafts offer a great source of free heat for ASHP.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531132998000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'117990844', u'id': u'118001251', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'this basically comes down to the way we finance energy now- a city development can make some savings on the final build by including some green heating and with some encouragement will start to include more of them- so benefiting the wider economy and encouraging a new business opportunity for 'river heat pump engineers'.
Likewise the move to solar was as much about developing a new economy with solar installers than it was about producing energy.
But this economic nudging has gone on for ages- when I was in conservation there was a new project that involved several £million [money from the EU and other dept] to develop new woodlands- most the cash was admin and employing staff to spread the message and get landowners to develop and expand their small woods for both the environment and small wood based business.It was about developing a new economy not protecting woodlands- simply spending the money on buying land and leaving it to nature would have had a far bigger impact.
and something as useful as recycling waste heat from a nuclear powerstation would have a huge benefit- but the economic opportunities are limited- the costs extremely high and ultimately no private investment to get the scheme going.It's the kind of thing the old soviet economy would have been very good at.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531132673000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'117989906', u'id': u'118000906', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'I would have thought the underground rivers harbour very little wildlife and that these schemes won't really impact the wildlife that is there.
Personally I would like to see some of these rivers restored to actual rivers', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531131028000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'117995865', u'id': u'117998989', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'BQSTART
and rely on up to two WSHP (Water Source Heat Pumps) depending upon the weather.
BQEND
I have come across these in yachting - but the only ones I can find are using the surface area of the hull to provide warmed air, or some preheating of the hot water system.
do you have a brand name or model, because I may [hopefully] have a canal narrow boat project where using canal water as the inlet supply would make a huge reduction in diesel heating use?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531132020000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'i may hopefully have a canal narrow boat project where using canal water as the inlet supply would make a huge reduction in diesel heating use', u'effect': u'do you have a brand name or model'}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'117992286', u'id': u'118000161', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'whitesocks', u'text': u'Anyone can make a basic mistake under a tight deadline.The real mystery is why they wouldn't want to correct it, when it was pointed out a number of times.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531131842000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1521543', u'in_reply_to': u'117987304', u'id': u'117999974', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JDaglish', u'text': u'In Rennes, France when they built the underground metro they embedded pipes in the stations to capture ground (mainly) and air waste heat for water source heat pumps to heat the surrounding residential building projects. http://www.faiteslepleindavenir.com/2015/04/14/quand-le-metro-chauffe-les-logements/
I dont think they have done anything with the Jubilee or Crossrail projects?
But TFL have used it on the Northern Line at Bunhill District heating scheme where the ventilation hot air is used by air sourced heat pumps.https://www.cibsejournal.com/technical/londons-tunnel-vision/', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531130321000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10472584', u'in_reply_to': u'117990844', u'id': u'117998141', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'It is actually very easy to make a heat exchanger for waste water- it is simply a reversed conventional coil hot water tank. However waste water going through a clean supply could involve the risk of contamination.CAT included on in their super green house in the 80s - to recycle heat from the hot water tank by pre heating it with water from the cold supply going through the coil of another standard hot water tank.But the amount of heat recovered is minor.To save some energy simply let your bath or washing up water cool before draining it.Latent heat in waste and sewage also serves a purpose in avoiding blockages in very cold weather!', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531131816000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'117993096', u'id': u'117999929', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'janey smit', u'text': u'weren't the covered on purpose by the victorians?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531130317000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18507475', u'id': u'117998133', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JDaglish', u'text': u'Domestic CO2 air source heat pump and 2 stage conventional air sourced refrigerant heat pumps produce 60C sufficient for standard radiator heating systems. 
But if you increase the surface are of the emitters eg oversized radiators, embedded floor or wall (the most efficient) heating, you can heat with low temperature (eg renewable) hot water ~ 35C. This of course depends on the energy performance (heat loss) of the property which as with fire regs the government as been horrendously neglectful in not putting in place updated building regulations to improve their performance. There are techniques that can be applied to old buildings without ruining their traditional facades.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531131365000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10472584', u'in_reply_to': u'117985109', u'id': u'117999397', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Campaigners propose using buried rivers as source of fossil fuel-free heat
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Campaigners propose using buried rivers as source of fossil fuel-free heat
og_fields.og:title: Lost rivers could heat London to cut capital's emissions
text:
Boris Johnson’s team wanted to uncover them for Londoners. The Environment Agency explored turning them into wildlife paradises. 
Now campaigners are targeting London’s lost rivers, water courses that have been gradually buried over the centuries, as a source of fossil fuel-free heat.
Rivers better known by the streets named after them – such the Fleet and the Strand – offer an inspiring way of cutting the capital’s emissions, the climate charity 10:10 and the social enterprise Scene said.
The refurbishment of Buckingham Palace, which includes plans for a new heating system and boilers, could be given a low-carbon boost by tapping the nearby Tyburn, according to an analysis by the groups.
The river could provide more heat than the palace uses even on the coldest day, they said.
The art deco Brockwell Lido in south London, meanwhile, could harness the heat in the adjacent river Effra. Extracting just a tenth of its energy would keep the pool – which dips to 2C in winter – warm all year round.
Another possibility highlighted by the groups is a new future-proofed heat network for four housing estates at Somers Town, north London, which could potentially one day draw heat from the river Fleet.
Leo Murray, the director of campaigns at 10:10, said: “The mayor has set ambitious targets for phasing out gas burning in London over the coming years and we are going to need every bit of low-carbon heat we can get our hands on to meet these goals.” 
Water-source heat pumps, which in effect work as a reverse refrigerator, would be used to extract the heat.
This could in turn be sent to housing estates and large buildings via heat networks, which the government has been backing as a way to decarbonise heating.
However, the study made no assessment of whether the pumps would be financially viable for projects and they are yet to be used at scale in the UK. 
The royal borough of Greenwich has been exploring the possibility of using water-source heat pumps to provide green heating for 100 homes at the refurbishment of the Ernest Dence estate but is still finalising its plans.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

[{u'type': u'http://schema.org/ImageObject', u'properties': {u'contentUrl': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/6eeabfddac63fb17f179ff984cfb59d9d2328f99/0_54_3888_2333/master/3888.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=eed3946f5ba43da552d0d9f5d2a884c0', u'description': u'Peter Wadhams gets most climate science right, but has been alarmist in his predictions about how soon the Arctic will be ice-free.

The causes can be unusually high temperatures that wither plants, drought that withers plants, deluges that drown plants, or new pests, viruses or weeds that overwhelm plants. If this happens on regional scale on several continents in the same growing season then all bets are off. These are all processes that happen in days or weeks. Our current climate models estimating the global average temperature rising 20-50 years from now do not resolve these risks. This is where Guy Mcpherson, Peter Wadhams and others are shouting out the alarm. Thanks to you and the other contributors.
But Betts has a point about the lists being political. As the article says, the focus is on the 'denier' side, because that is where the meaningful political damage is being done. The excuse of time seems a touch disingenuous - there isn't time because you don't see it as significant, and it isn't significant because of the lack of political impact.
Plus, of course, the fact that policy lags mainstream Science, means that (on a binary action/ inaction view) alarmism is at least pulling in the right direction, even if from the wrong position.
But there are 2 other points to consider. The first is that alarmism fuels denial - Wadhams may be one of the most cited scientists on denial blogs. Or look at the ongoing interest in Himalayan glaciers from one minor paragraph in an old IPCC report, or a handful of cooling predictions in the 70s. A public demonstration that these are fringe positions - at the time - makes mainstream science more robust. There is real value to calling them out.
Second, if we focus only on deniers, then they are dictating the terms. Of course they must be called out and corrected, and I'm grateful for those doing this. But equally they should not influence our thinking - even to the extent of turning a blind eye to fringe errors because they are 'on our side'. It shouldn't be about sides. Denialists have made it so. Okay it's only a blog, but is it impossible for the attitude to percolate out? Political impartiality to errors both adds to perceived credibility and to actual robustness.
Granted it's all volunteers, and you can do what you want. But maybe basing your responses on the prominence, rather than the 'politics', of the flawed argument is all that's needed. As said in the article this would still mean a ~95% focus on denial, but with a bit of space for the more high profile alarmist claims to be dealt with before they crop up on denial blogs as proof of failed predictions.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531558290000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that is where the meaningful political damage is being done', u'effect': u'as the article says the focus is on the side'}, {u'cause': u"you do n't see it as significant", u'effect': u"the excuse of time seems a touch disingenuous there is n't time and it is n't significant because of the lack of political impact"}, {u'cause': u'the lack of political impact', u'effect': u"it is n't significant"}, {u'cause': u'they are on our side', u'effect': u'but equally they should not influence our thinking even to the extent of turning a blind eye to fringe errors'}], u'author_id': u'3919949', u'id': u'118260623', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'loco_p_man', u'text': u'BQSTART

t's just an opinion based on models, models are not evidence, and certainly not a consensus opinion.
BQENDAll of physics is simply models.
Models are a way of abstracting the complex real world into a mathematically description than can be used to produce estimates of future behaviour of isolated systems in the physical world.
For example Newtonian physics' famous F=m*a is nothing but a model used to describe the behaviour of a particle under a force. 
What we know is that some models are better at describing the world than others. The models of the ocean\atmosphere system that use CO2 as a greenhouse gas have had success in predicting the long term changes in temperature. These models also predict 
Here we have a comparison between the data from CIMP5 RCP 4.5 and the Cowtan and Way global surface temperature dataset 
Not only are the models broadly right in long term temperature, they get where it will get warm very correct as well. 
(CIMP5 from IPCC AR5 WG1 and Cowtan and Way 2014 here.  )

BQENDIn my experience people with a weak grasp on details tend to rewrite their meaning as they go along.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531669725000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'118292759', u'id': u'118307890', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"So can I 'add CO2 to the atmosphere' without increasing 'CO2 in the atmosphere'?
You can if you do it by exhaling the CO2 from the food you have metabolised which you should remember was what you were talking about.
All the CO2 exhaled by you and the 7.4 billion other people in this world (just to put you in perspective) can be added to the atmosphere without increasing the CO2 in the atmosphere as homeothermic animals such as you metabolise at the same rate all year round and the CO2 they exhale was turned into the food they metabolise but months to a year before. There is a balance between plants absorbing CO2 to produce homeothermic animal food and those animals metabolising and exhaling CO2. Plants can only absorb so much CO2 and produce so much homeothermic animal food. As there is only so much homeothermic animal food for them to metabolise, those animals can only exhale so much CO2 - hence the balance resulting in no net increase in CO2 in the atmosphere from the exhalations of homeothermic animals such as you.
"Can I also, therefore, 'subtract CO2 from the atmosphere' without decreasing "CO2 in the atmosphere'? 
As a homeothermic animal you cannot absorb or subtract CO2 from the atmosphere. However, you can plant a tree which will absorb CO2 from the atmosphere. If you and the 7.4 other people on the Earth planted many more trees and preserved the wood they produced as building material on a very large scale you and the other 7.4 billion people could absorb enough CO2 to reduce the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere provide it wasn't being added by other means and provided the wood was not burnt, allowed to rot or be eaten by termites. Once the wood rots, burns or is eaten by termites and metabolised there is no net decrease in the CO2 in the atmosphere.
The reality at present though is that CO2 is being added to the atmosphere by the combustion of fossil fuels in amounts far greater than the ability of plants to absorb that CO2, resulting in a net increase in atmospheric CO2.
Fossil fuels are the CO2 that was absorbed years ago by forests and preserved by burial. This process still goes on today in what's left of swampland, peatland and subsiding deltas. But we're digging it up or extracting it faster than it is being produced. We're burning it and producing CO2 from it faster than our Earth can absorb and sequester that CO2, resulting in a large net increase in atmospheric CO2 of more than 40% over the last 150 years.
The logic of science is based on the evidence gathered by scientists that enables to understand the real world. Where you are getting confused in in understanding how the real world works.
Can I add money to my bank account over the month of July without increasing the amount of money in my account for that. You bet I can if I spend the money before the month is out.
Can also withdraw money from my bank account for the month of July without decreasing the amount of money in my account for that month. I can if there is a salary coming in which is greater than the amount of money I withdrew for the month.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531322668000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'no net increase in co2 in the atmosphere from the exhalations of homeothermic animals such as you'}, {u'cause': u'co2', u'effect': u'a net increase in atmospheric co2'}, {u'cause': u'co2', u'effect': u'a large net increase in atmospheric co2 of more than 40 % over the last 150 years'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118126813', u'id': u'118132106', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'In 16 days time I'll also have been around for 68 years. The last time there was global warming sea level rise lagged warming by around 200 years. Why do you think it would be different this time? When I walk the same paths as I did 60 years ago I find myself being bitten by a species of Culicoides midge that then was found 200 km further north. When I walk along the reef edge I walked along 50 years ago I see vast areas if dead coral. An alarmist is someone who exaggerates a danger. What dangers are being exaggerated?', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531487337000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118154207', u'id': u'118230807', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'BQSTART
And don't forget about NAS's cooling prediction.
BQENDThe 1976 NAS report on climate did suggest a cooling trend since 1940 had interrupted the longer warming trend, but made no predictions of it continuing.
One can read that very dated report here. 
 https://archive.org/details/understandingcli00unit
Within a couple of years it had released the Charney Report https://www.nap.edu/catalog/12181/carbon-dioxide-and-climate-a-scientific-assessment
That is broadly in line with current predictions.So both the alarmist clowns and the denialist buffoons are out of step with the long term scientific consensus.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531375297000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'118147182', u'id': u'118155740', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ArcticMelt', u'text': u'There is so much that is alarming about the environment. Obviously the "alarmists" will be seen as correct ,just had the dates a little off.Denialists as totally wrong bec they do what the fossil fuel corporations want', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531660864000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12760337', u'id': u'118303420', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'"Newton's Laws..."That's a fair cop; sloppy wavering whether to use gravity or thermodynamics in the sentence- piss poor.The rest of your post, unfortunately, is your usual desperate, near pathological search for a fight against anybody you can find. Eg-"The science consensus is a contingent and rationally arguable..."Is it the word 'contingent' that is upsetting you? I simply mean that the 'consensus' is 'contingent' upon the accumulating evidence of research continuing to support it. If you find that genuinely unacceptable, rather than something to arbitrarily snit over, please explain why."Racial Hegeine (sic) and Eugenics...."I said that Nazism could not have been considered part of a scientific 'consensus'. Racial Hegeine (sic) and Eugenics were not "Nazism", which is a particular political ideology; and are you telling me that there was a scientific consensus about Racial Hegeine comparable to the consensus now on AGW? "Part of the scientific discussion" is not quite synonymous, is it?"Simply having "public papers" or something does not make something scientific". Firstly, the idea of quote-marks is that the writing between them is a quote. The phrase was "publicly readable papers", ie, I was merely emphasising that science papers are part of an open discussion, not an esoteric private forum of the sort suggested by the 'consensus' of online-paedophiles suggested by the OP. I notice you have no issues, by the way, with such analogies yourself. As to whether being the subject of a published scientific paper does or does not "make something scientific"- I didn't actually make that assertion either, so once again you're fighting over your own inability to read. The rest of your post is merely arse-waving in your usual baboon style, which I'm sure makes you pleased, so that's good.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531321702000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'118123140', u'id': u'118131381', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'I read "What is this thing called Science?" by A F Chalmers a while ago, which talks about Kuhn's Paradigm ideas quite a bit- I liked Chalmer's book, full of intelligent uncertainty. There a nice quote from Durrell in the front- "Like all young men I set out to be a genius, but mercifully laughter intervened." TT would writhe with indignant contempt.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531482172000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'118150493', u'id': u'118225382', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'BQSTART

:) :) :) :) : :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :)
BQENDA level of intellectual rigor I could never aspire too.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531374508000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'118154894', u'id': u'118155477', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'So you now admit the science is correct and we must reduce emissions as soon as practicable.
Excellent.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531651637000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'118293579', u'id': u'118297154', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'“These two quotes are not the same in content or meaning.”
Yes they are.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531321157000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'118113927', u'id': u'118130933', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Will people get alarmed in September when the global temperature cools for the next six months? No, people know that happens every year at about that time.
No one's denying that such cooling of global average yearly temperatures has occurred but if you check the records you'll see that such such cooling of global average yearly temperatures over a three year period has occurred many times before. 
Did people get alarmed when average yearly temperatures dropped as the 2015-16 extreme El Nino transitioned to the borderline La Nina/neutral ENSO phases of 2016-17 and the weak La Nina of 2017-18? No of course not. It's what they expected would happen.
Why didn't you check the records to see that such events characterise the record of yearly global average temperature?
It's irrational on your part to ignore the variability in the records and suggest that what happens over three years has any bearing on climate which takes tens times as long to shed that yearly variability.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531475616000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118108715', u'id': u'118218481', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531374220000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'118155317', u'id': u'118155387', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Yes, sure, there are some who have overemphasized the immediacy of ice loss and sea level rise. This is not my point. I asked you instead to consider the doomsday scenario of those who are cynical promoters of euthanasia.
A stylistic tip: In future try to make it clear when you are only quoting yourself. Not the best practice in any case, but it could be confusing to someone who hasn't read the complete correspondence of Stella Body.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531649345000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'118288761', u'id': u'118295534', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Lying and then seeing people rebut it is no great achievement. Global temperatures can only be said to be falling if you don't understand either a) numbers of b) graphs.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531320365000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'118108715', u'id': u'118130145', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'This is just stream of conscious waffle. You have not read what I said and are certainly not responding too it. 
1) Most of you avoid solid sources because you have no clue what the mainstream of this science actually says. And its hard work to track down a good source, obviously you lot will not knuckle down and learn a little. 2) Most places that are set up as actual science forums expect hypothesis, theories or data to be supported by good sources. BTL Guardian Environment is deeply antiscience in its tone and methods. 3) I have highlighted my reasons why good sources are preferred you are clearly incapable of engaging with what I said. 
Most of you are here to play act, you pretend to be knowledgeable about a field you often have little idea of the very basics. The other reason you turn up is to shout abuse at "deniers". The actual topic of the thread is usually avoided unless that topic "worse than we thought!". 
The endless recycling of a small number of quotes is basically presenting a highly distorted view of the state of climate science in the same way that Judith Curries blog contributors do. Same method, different agenda.
Whining that TV shows do not use peer reviewed sources is absurd. Good ones do, they just do not reference it in the show because it is experts (and no you lot are really really really not experts) providing infotainment. 
You will likely not understand this and answer completely different points.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531317277000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you have no clue what the mainstream of this science actually says', u'effect': u'most of you avoid solid sources'}, {u'cause': u'it is experts', u'effect': u'good ones do they just do not reference it in the show'}], u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'118125832', u'id': u'118127529', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The pause in what? There has been no pause in the warming of the Earth's climate. Between the extreme El Nino of 1997-98 and the extreme El Nino of 2015-16 there was a period with no extreme El Nino years and hence a lower rate of rise of yearly average global temperature. This is explained by the reduced trade wind activity during extreme El Ninos compared to the stronger trade winds in between. Strong trade winds mix warm surface waters into deeper water warming the ocean at depth and decreasing surface temperature. Weak trade winds cause less mixing and higher surface temperatures. There is no missing heat, just more heat deeper in the oceans.
Similarly the cooling of surface temperatures in 2016 and 2017 after the extreme El Nino of 2015-16 is explained by the increased trade winds due to the neutral/ weak La Nina of 2016-17 and the weak La Nina of 2017-18.
The global cooling that will occur from September through to March is due to the Northern Hemisphere winter which because of the greater land surface in the hemisphere results in a cooler global temperature for that time period.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531466027000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'weak trade winds', u'effect': u'less mixing and higher surface temperatures'}, {u'cause': u'the neutral/ weak la nina of 2016 17 and the weak la nina of 2017 18', u'effect': u'the increased trade winds'}, {u'cause': u'the greater land surface in the hemisphere results in a cooler global temperature for that time period', u'effect': u'due to the Northern Hemisphere winter which because of the greater land surface in the hemisphere results in a cooler global temperature for that time period'}, {u'cause': u'the greater land surface in for that time period', u'effect': u'a cooler global temperature'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118184570', u'id': u'118208642', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'BQSTART
I've been around for 68 years during the largest amount of global warming and CO2 increase. The sea level is still the same, I walk the same paths as I did 60 years ago. there is no change, or if there is its imperceptible
BQENDUnfortunately unlike yourself and the others who have responded, I tend to work with data, not anecdotes.
Here is Rahmstorf 2012
You are looking for figure 8 on page 869.Most of the sea level rise that is projected has not happened yet. 
What is more the sea level we have seen has been in keeping with the projections.
These pages are riddled with what can only be called attention seeking buffoons who use antiscience methodologies. 
Someone who has not taken the time to learn what the projections are (like most contributors) and then critiques them is not someone to be taken seriously.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531374001000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'118150534', u'id': u'118155317', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ATHERIS', u'text': u'Population size and growth is treated as a taboo subject but there is no prospect of reaching a state of sustainable world unless people face up to the population issue. The global population is growing every year. At the same time people in emerging economies are increasing their carbon footprint. The use of cars, air conditioning and refrigerators is growing at record levels. Who can blame them?
We face mass extinctions, growing shortages of some resources and the proliferation of waste materials contaminating the planet. Carbon reduction programmes are necessary but they won't solve the problem on their own.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531646563000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12689317', u'id': u'118293579', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernie Thomas', u'text': u'"You add CO2 to the atmosphere but you do not add net CO2 to the atmosphere, so the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere does not increase."
So I can "add CO2 to the atmosphere" without increasing "CO2 in the atmosphere"?
Can I also, therefore "subtract CO2 from the atmosphere" without decreasing "CO2 in the atmosphere"? 
There is a certain "climate sciency logic" here that escapes me. Oh well... my loss. I guess. Thanks Walsunda. No further questions.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531316383000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17746707', u'in_reply_to': u'118102398', u'id': u'118126813', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The consensus among 97% of the authors of published climate science papers which discuss the cause of the global warming seen since the 19th century is that it is the result of CO2 produced by human activities.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531464849000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118184475', u'id': u'118207839', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'BQSTART
I've been around for 68 years and ...
BQEND
Earth resolves around the Sun.:) :) :) :) : :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :)', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531372512000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'118154207', u'id': u'118154894', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northforce', u'text': u'I've been around for 68 years during the largest amount of global warming and CO2 increase. The sea level is still the same, I walk the same paths as I did 60 years ago.there is no change, or if there is its imperceptible, so yes they are alarmist, that's their job, that's what they were created to do.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531369911000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18157694', u'in_reply_to': u'118152633', u'id': u'118154207', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidFTA', u'text': u'That's a fairly comprehensive list, and I guess it's fine for the UK or wherever you live. For Australia where I live, instead of the plethora of regulations which you propose, a Fossil Carbon Consumption Tax (FCCT), the rate of which is increased every year with the additional revenue raised used to adjust any and all other taxes and benefits to avoid undue strains and injustices on an economy (i.e. a pure price signal) would achieve optimal technological transformation (including energy efficiency) by itself.
As for my telling you to be the first to fuck off to a cave, that's my response to your "regardless how 'inconvenient' it makes your life"; turns out you were simply big-noting yourself. 
PS It's irreplaceable resource consumption that's unsustainable; an economy can continue to grow indefinitely provided growth is derived from innovations in <I>how</I> the same finite resources are used and re-used, not on the use of ever-greater quantities of finite resources.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531315486000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4644463', u'in_reply_to': u'118109123', u'id': u'118126158', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"There was no statistical increase in temperatures for the time period 2000 to 2014."
In two months time global temperatures will decline rather than increase for six months. That happens every year.
The average global surface temperature for 2017 was less than that for 2016 which was less than 2015. So there was cooling over the three year time period 2015 to 2017.
What do these three pieces of information tell us about climate change in response to global warming?
Absolutely nothing.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531463878000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118150536', u'id': u'118207248', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northforce', u'text': u'It's just an opinion based on models, models are not evidence, and certainly not a consensus opinion.Yawn..', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531369710000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18157694', u'in_reply_to': u'118152633', u'id': u'118154177', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'There seems to be a continuing trend in debate highlighted by the popular Jordan Peterson that starts with a premise- that is untrue. In Peterson's case it is the power of a [mysterious] group of neo Marxist post modernists and in yours the premise that there is a debate between those who demand only peer review and those who demand only 'quotes' [and just as neo marxist post modernist makes no sense so does 'quotes'].
Returning to Erik's OP - he makes the case that those who write the studies should also be listened to when they speak more casually [i.e. in interviews or opeds]- not the either / or position you seem to be claiming.
The issue I was focusing on is science communication- most people are not equipped to disseminate peer reviewed literature, no because they are stupid but simply unskilled in the same way physicists may get the builders in for an extension or glaciologists rely on the dentist for tooth care.Even scientists are not equipped to venture to far outside their own areas of study given the level specialisation.Communication is a challenge, now you may say that should not matter- that we simply have process of science- policy [divised by policy makers] - politics -action. fine for non democratic states, but we have that tricky thing called freedom.On the one hand we have those challenging mainstream AGW science to influence public opinion and then politics and therefore policy on action and on the other policy makers and politicians telling the public to trust them on this. As recent popularist politics has demonstrated- 'the public has had enough of experts' which is disturbing.just as scientists are not trained to be dentists or builders so they are not trained as public figures or journalists. Some do break into the public sphere like Carl Sagan, Neil deGrasse Tyson [who stopped doing science in the 90s to move across to more public engagement] Brian Cox and James Hansen. Stephen Hawking even appeared in popular tv such as Big Bang and Star Trek.
These science communicators rely on peer reviewed science but they don't just read it out straight from the text books. The problem with science papers is that they will not communicate what it means to people on a personal, cultural and societal level. When Jim Hansen and other scientists write about the need for nuclear power and the inadequacies of renewables they are coming with an opinion outside of their field- but one they have thought about- and as such it is open for debate. When Mackay wrote 'without hot air' it was for public digestion, it was not a peer reviewed science paper- and it opened up debate. Those on the pro nuclear side will use the authority of the 'quoters'/'quotes' as an argument, just as AGW denial will use the quotes from retired physicists.i suppose it comes down to what healthy debate [on opinions] is, get it right and it is good for democracy - but if it is heavily influenced by bias in any extreme then it needs fixing.AGW outcomes are huge and vary from one extreme to the other- although likelihood diminishes at those extremes, and as a species we are not very good at being logical as to what it means.There may be some who prefer quotes/opinions over the scientific consensus but as long as that derives from the consensus it is not for you to be thread monitor or BTL police.And if you want to stay pure to 'message' no one is criticising you for that. Glacier and Rocky do it all the the time.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531315038000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they are stupid but simply unskilled in the same way', u'effect': u'most people are not equipped to disseminate peer reviewed literature no'}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'118118191', u'id': u'118125832', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Malware', u'text': u'And the thickness of the ice was massive compared to today's volume. It's not just a question of extent but also of volume. We have lost the multi-year ice that was a feature of the Arctic.
https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/4510', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531312834000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4243084', u'in_reply_to': u'118032525', u'id': u'118124011', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Note, as the rate of continual withdrawal by natural sequestration is greater that the rate of deposit by exhalation there is no temporary existence of the latter beyond a 12 hour period period and therefore exhalation has no effect upon the account balance. It is the much larger inputs into the atmospheric CO2 account by combustion of fossil fuels at a rate greater than natural sequestration that has an effect which unfortunately is not temporary.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531441818000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118180416', u'id': u'118203930', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northforce', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531441641000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'18157694', u'in_reply_to': u'118163178', u'id': u'118203886', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Dana Nuccitelli: Deniers have conservative media outlets and control the Republican Party; climate alarmists are largely ignored
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Deniers have conservative media outlets and control the Republican Party; climate alarmists are largely ignored
og_fields.og:title: There are genuine climate alarmists, but they're not in the same league as deniers | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Those who debunk climate change misinformation often face a dilemma. We’re flooded with such a constant deluge of climate myths, where should we focus our efforts? Climate misinformation is propagated via congressional climate hearings, conservative media outlets, denial blogs, and even from some genuine climate alarmists. 
Specifically, there has recently been a debate as to whether Skeptical Science – a website with a database of climate myths and scientific debunkings, to which I’m a primary contributor – would be more useful and effective if it called out misinformation from ‘alarmists,’ and if it eliminated or revised its Climate Misinformers page.
I describe the SkS lists as political because their 'misinformer' lists don't include those on the 'climate action' side who actively deny science & espouse conspiracy ideation eg. https://t.co/OTkhEiKmzv or who unjustifiably talk-up doomsday stories https://t.co/faGCDQCevx
There is some validity to these critiques, and in response, Skeptical Science is renaming the page ‘Climate misinformation by source.’ But the site is run entirely by a team of international volunteers, and as such, opportunity costs must be considered. Time devoted to refuting alarmists is time not devoted to debunking the constant deluge of climate denial.
Climate deniers are obviously incredibly influential. Despite their lack of supporting evidence or facts, not only do 28% of Americans continue to believe that global warming is natural and 14% that it’s not even happening, but deniers also dictate Republican Party policy. Republican policymakers constantly invite deniers to testify in congressional hearings, including many of those featured on the Skeptical Science misinformers page.
There is no symmetry on the other side of the aisle. In those same congressional hearings, Democratic Party policymakers invite mainstream climate scientists to testify. Their party policy is based on the consensus of 97% of the climate science community. 
Ultimately, the issue boils down to a warped ‘Overton Window’ – the range of ideas tolerated in public discourse. In the real world, we have climate deniers on one extreme, alarmists on the other, and mainstream climate science in the middle. But the public discourse is warped – we instead have a heavy focus on climate denial among conservative media outlets and policymakers, a heavy focus on mainstream climate science among reputable media outlets and liberal policymakers, and the alarmists are largely ignored. Michael Tobis nicely diagrammed this in the climate Overton Window:
That being said, there are a few reasonably well-known individuals who could be accurately described as climate alarmists. The most prominent is Guy McPherson, who decided in 2002 that climate change would likely drive humans to extinction by 2030. Sixteen years later, we’re now more than halfway to 2030 and the global human population has grown from 6.3 bn to 7.6 bn. It’s quite safe to say we won’t go extinct in the next few decades.
McPherson’s case basically boils down to arguing that feedbacks like large methane releases will soon kick in, causing a rapid spike in global warming that will lead to global extinctions. One of his primary pieces of supporting evidence is that Earth System Sensitivity – which describes how sensitive the climate is to the increased greenhouse effect over millennia – is higher than the shorter-term climate sensitivity.
That was essentially the gist of a recent study profiled here in the Guardian. Over millennia, global temperatures and sea level rise will continue to rise beyond what climate models predict will happen over the next couple of centuries. But these are slow feedbacks, and as such won’t kick in within the next few decades. Scott Johnson did a very deep dive into McPherson’s flawed arguments, for those who want to learn about them in greater detail.
As another example, Peter Wadhams predicted in 2012 that the Arctic would be ice-free in the summer by 2016. In fact, the summer of 2012 saw a dramatic decline in year-to-year Arctic sea ice extent (down to 3.6 million square km), which Wadhams believed would become the norm. That hasn’t yet been the case – there were 4.7 million square km of Arctic sea ice in the summer of 2016.
It’s worth noting that Wadhams gets most of the climate science right. There is absolutely a long-term decline in Arctic sea ice, which is in the midst of what many have described as a ‘death spiral.’ And Arctic sea ice is thinning rapidly. The Arctic will eventually be ice-free in the summer, but not within the next few years. According to Met Office Chief Scientist Julia Slingo, 2025–2030 would be the earliest date for an ice-free Arctic summer, and 2040–2060 is more likely. Wadhams also believes that there may soon be a large methane release from the Arctic, but a review of the relevant research suggests this isn’t a near-term concern:
There is no evidence that methane will run out of control and initiate any sudden, catastrophic effects. There’s certainly no runaway greenhouse. Instead, chronic methane releases will supplement the primary role of CO2. 
Wadhams has received some mainstream media attention, including in the Guardian, but his more alarmist warnings are largely ignored. There certainly isn’t a powerful political party basing its climate policies on his inaccurate predictions. 
And that’s really the key point. While there are people on ‘both sides’ who spread misinformation, there are far more on the denier than the alarmist side, who are generally far wronger, and the deniers also have a far greater influence over policymakers. 
There’s certainly nothing wrong with debunking overly alarmist claims – in fact, it’s a worthwhile endeavor, and some groups like Climate Feedback do just that. But debunking uninfluential alarmism comes at a cost. It diverts resources away from addressing the never-ending flood of misinformation coming from climate deniers who currently control the climate policy platform of the party in charge of one of the most powerful countries on Earth.
… we have a small favour to ask. More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

article_tags: [Climate change, Environment, US news, US weather]
description: The record-breaking high temperatures across much of North America appear to be shaping people’s thinking, a survey finds
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: The record-breaking high temperatures across much of North America appear to be shaping people’s thinking, a survey finds
og_fields.og:title: Heatwave seems to make manmade climate change real for Americans
text:
The warm temperatures that have scorched much of the US appear to be influencing Americans’ acceptance of climate science, with a new poll finding a record level of public confidence that the world is warming due to human activity.
A long-running survey of American attitudes to climate change has found that 73% of people now think there is solid evidence of global warming. A further 60% believe that this warming is due, at least in some part, to human influences.
Both of these findings are record highs in a twice-yearly survey that has been conducted by the University of Michigan and Muhlenberg College since 2008. The latest poll was conducted during May, which was hotter than any May recorded in the contiguous US in 124 years of record keeping, according to the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration, eclipsing the 1930s during the Dust Bowl era. 
“There’s lots of evidence that contemporary weather is a contributing factor to belief in climate change,” said Chris Borick, director of the Muhlenberg College Institute of Public Opinion. “But there are other factors. People are telling us they are experiencing a climate that isn’t what they remember in the past and the evidence itself, such as declining polar ice, is having an effect. Americans are moving to a lot more confident space on this.”
But there remains a yawning ideological divide when it comes to climate change in the US. The survey found that while 90% of Democrats accept there is solid evidence of climate change, only 50% of Republicans feel the same. 
However, Borick said that messaging from those who deny or obfuscate climate science has shifted away from outright rejection of temperature data. While Donald Trump has previously called climate change “bullshit” and a Chinese-inspired hoax, he has rarely spoken of the issue while president apart from framing action to address it as economically costly. 
“The talking points have turned more to the cost to mitigate climate change rather than deny its existence,” Borick said. “That said, if you want one factor that influences your view on climate change, it’s party affiliation. Age, race and gender don’t even come close.”
The hot temperatures have persisted in much of the country since the May survey, with Los Angeles hitting a monthly overnight record of 79F (26.1C) on 7 July. Chino, near Los Angeles, saw a record temperature of 120F (48.9C), while Death Valley in California reached 125.6F (52C) on 8 July.
About 80 million Americans have been placed under heat warnings in recent weeks, with cities such as Denver, Colorado and Cheyenne, Wyoming, both experiencing record temperatures. 
The heat has been fierce on the US east coast and Canada, too. About 70 deaths have been blamed upon a punishing heatwave experienced in and around Montreal, with further deaths recorded in New York and Pennsylvania due to the high temperatures.
A string of warm days in New York City helped trigger a return to smog-like conditions on 2 July, when the temperature in the city reached 95F (35C).
Researchers who flew a light aircraft taking measurements over a hazy New York were astonished to find that the ozone concentration was 150 parts per billion. This far exceeds the Environmental Protection Agency’s eight-hour average ozone health standard of 70 parts per billion. The high ozone readings have continued, with preliminary data for Tuesday showing 85 parts per billion in New York.
Ground-level ozone is created when pollutants react to intense sunlight, potentially causing haze or smog. This can cause serious health problems and even death for people who are elderly, sick or who have respiratory conditions.
“This is a disturbingly high level, we were very surprised at the results,” said Russell Dickerson, a professor at the University of Maryland’s department of atmospheric and oceanic science. “The sky was very gray. It reminded me of Beijing. It was like what New York used to be like, before it cleaned itself up.”
Overall air quality in the US has improved markedly in recent decades following the introduction of federal clean air rules. Ozone levels have remained stubbornly high in New York, however.
“We are trying to work out why this is but the recent high level could well be because of the hot, stagnant weather, with weak winds,” Dickerson said. “It’s a public health concern. I’d certainly advise people to stay indoors during the hottest part of the day.”
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for humanity and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. A paper from the PAGES2K project is an example, and here's a key reconstruction from their data:
http://d35brb9zkkbdsd.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/PAGES2k_MBH991.png
The red curve shows the global mean temperature, based on HadCRUT4 data from 1850 onwards.
In blue is the original "hockey stick" from a paper by Mann, Bradley and Hughes (1999) with its uncertainty range (light blue).
The green dots are calculated using data from many places around the world, using information from a range of temperature proxies, such as documents, ice, lakes, pollen, tree rings, corals, seabeds and speleothems.
Here's the link to the paper from which the green dot points are derived:
http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v6/n5/full/ngeo1797.html
*speleothems are dripstones/stalagmites/stalactites.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531509015000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'118247922', u'id': u'118248542', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'So you are comparing all the physicists, chemists, geologists, and so forth you have studied the changing climate with homeopaths. But there are many micro dairies popping up, all about the place.
Believe it or not those cow keepers are making a small living from a few milkers, and direct selling. They're subverting the 'extractive' supermarket model - the consumer gets really fresh wholesome milk - farmer gets a proper wage.
But instead of moving far out into the country, we need more skilled growers and farmers to stay in or around conurbations and produce food there, where it will be consumed.
The land around cities is usually very fertile - this is often why the city sprung up there in the first place. This is where our fresh food should be produced.
There is definitely an unequal concentration of too much land in too few hands in this country and its getting worse with consolidation of farms.
The aggro biz model is broken in so many ways - economically - ecologically - and socially - it doesn't produce healthy nourishment - it mainly produces cheap calories which have deleterious effect...
Oh and some big ol profits for supermarket, suppliers of enormous machinery, and agrochemical suppliers .
Many conventional farmers barely break even - they are chasing diminishing returns - and once they are operating in a global marketplace - and their area payment (EU money ) is taken away - they will be truly stuffed - this is not the fault of the farmer -its the system that they are in.

Ice is melting all over the planet because the world is above average in temperature. The N hemisphere is above average, the S hemisphere is above average, the Arctic is way above average, the tropics are above average, the Antarctic is above average.
We have thermometers analyzed by NASA, NOAA, the British Met Office, the Japanese, the Berkeley group.
If you throw away every thermometer in the city, temperatures in the country show warming.
Thermometers in the ground show warming, thermometers in the ocean show the ocean is warming, thermometers in balloons show warming, looking down from satellites they show warming.
Warmer air contains more moisture, so some areas are seeing storms with heavier than usual snowfall, such as Boston in some of the last few years.
But if you look at the snow and ice that care about temperature the most, we have less river ice than we used to, less lake ice, less seasonal snow cover, less seasonally frozen ground, less perennially frozen ground, we have smaller glaciers, we have shrinking ice sheets, we have loss of sea ice.

BQSTART
Last weekend, Chinese scientists released a separate report that said the surface area of glaciers on Mount Everest, which straddles the Tibet-Nepal border, have shrunk nearly 30 percent in the last 40 years.
Vanishing glaciers raise urgent concerns beyond Tibet and China.
By one estimate, the 46,000 glaciers of the Third Pole region help sustain 1.5 billion people in 10 countries — its waters flowing to places as distant as the tropical Mekong Delta of Vietnam, the hills of eastern Myanmar and the southern plains of Bangladesh. Scattered across nearly two million square miles, these glaciers are receding at an ever-quickening pace, producing a rise in levels of rivers and lakes in the short term and threatening Asia’s water supply in the long run.
A paper published this year by The Journal of Glaciology said the retreat of Asian glaciers was emblematic of a “historically unprecedented global glacier decline.”
“I would say that climatologically, we are in unfamiliar territory, and the world’s ice cover is responding dramatically,” said Lonnie G. Thompson, a glaciologist at Ohio State University who helped found a project to study climate change on the Tibetan Plateau.
BQEND
