BQSTART
The Met Office is grateful for this opportunity to clarify its position regarding the doubts expressed in the preceding paper, and in Part 1, published in the August issue, over the temperature recorded on 10 August 2003 at Faversham. As noted in the paper, there are in fact good grounds for accepting the value of 38.5 C on 10 August in that: (i) the Faversham site and equipment are maintained to accepted standards; the reading was made independently by two trained observers; and (iii) after the event the maximum thermometer was demonstrated to be accurate to within 0.1 degc. In addition, the synoptic situation over southern England that day favoured the highest temperatures being achieved inland over and to the east of London. A further factor is that whilst Faversham was Table 1 Maximum temperatures recorded during August 2003 Date Faversham East Wye Difference Difference ( C) Malling ( C) Faversham Faversham ( C) East Malling Wye (degc) (degc) warmer than its inland neighbours (East Malling and Wye) on the 10th, this was not a systematic difference on the other heatwave days (see Table 1). The varying differences recorded during the heatwave are typical of hot days over the previous 40 years and attributable to a variety of circumstances, as noted in the paper. Study of possible contributing mesoscale factors, such as the effect of the North Downs in a southerly airstream, might provide a reason for the differences on this occasion. One of the things that makes the UK weather so fascinating is that it can occasionally produce extremes that might seem unlikely, yet nevertheless have been recorded carefully under standard conditions. Rejection of an observed value, particularly one that indicates an unusual or extreme event, should only happen when there are good reasons to believe that the measurement was erroneous or made in non-standard conditions. The evidence is that the Faversham maximum temperature on 10 August 2003 was recorded correctly, in a favourable synoptic situation, and so should continue to be regarded as the current UK record. Senior Press Officer Met Office,
BQEND
If the record were abandoned against the Met offices judgement then the record would be 38.1C at Kew. description: I hoped 2003’s record heatwave would make people more aware of climate change, says the journalist and naturalist Michael McCarthy
og_fields.og:description: I hoped 2003’s record heatwave would make people more aware of climate change, says the journalist and naturalist Michael McCarthy
og_fields.og:title: Fahrenheit 100: could this be the summer Britain wakes up to climate change? | Michael McCarthy
text:
I don’t know anybody who remembers 10 August 2003 and its significance, although the date has never faded from my mind. That was Britain’s hottest ever day, the day the current British air temperature record was set: it leapt from the old record of 37.1C, set on 3 August 1990, to the new figure of 38.5C.
Those bare numbers may not mean much to you, though they may well appear more meaningful if you convert them to fahrenheit. For the old record was 98.8F,but the new one was 101.3F, and that meant that the 100F barrier had been broken in Britain for the first time ever. It seemed to me then, as it does now, that this was a hugely symbolic crossing of an environmental threshold; yet the population instantly forgot all about it.
The current heatwave bids fair to be the longest period of sustained hot weather since the fabled summer of 1976. But will it actually be the hottest? Might we actually see a new British record air temperature? Local records are already being broken and there was a brief flurry of excitement 10 days ago when it appeared that the Scottish national record had been smashed with a temperature of 33.2C (91.7F) recorded in Motherwell, but now the Met Office has rejected the claim because a vehicle with its engine running was too close to the thermometer.
It seems a new British record is certainly possible this summer that, if achieved, would give considerable force to the suggestion that the very high temperatures that have been in evidence all over the northern hemisphere this summer are at least partly the product of global warming, rather than just natural variation.
For anyone interested in following and watching out for this, I have a suggestion: keep your eye on the fahrenheit as well as the celsius measurement it will mean more. I say this as a baby boomer who grew up with F rather than C; it was not until 1962 that the Met Office adopted celsius, and in my early childhood I acquired the instinctive feel that everybody then had (and people still have in the US), which told you that, in fahrenheit terms, 60 was pleasantly warm, and 70 was really lovely weather, and 80 was seriously hot, while 90 represented the sort of heatwave that was a major event. Anything approaching 90 would result in front-page headlines in the Daily Express proclaiming: “88 … 89 … 90! Phew! What a scorcher!”
That was the point about the 100 figure. It was off the map. It had never been recorded in meteorological history, in the daily temperature records that go back to 1772. But it had no place in cultural history either. There was no reference point for it: no stories, no memories, no jokes, no newspaper headlines. In our native land of showers and cool summers, 100 degrees fahrenheit represented an unknown country.
The round number certainly helped. In celsius terms, 100F is 37.8C, and of course 37.8C as such isn’t any sort of figure the mind will register, any sort of boldly marked frontier whose breaching will seem significant. But once you represent it in fahrenheit, the move up from two digits to three has a symbolical significance of real power.
That’s what I thought, anyway, in the years I spent writing about climate change and being something of a temperature nerd, waiting for the 100 mark to be hit, for “the ton to be up”. When the 100F threshold is broken, I thought, everyone will see at once that we are in new territory in terms of climate; everyone will perceive the reality of global warming, in an instinctive way. And in August 2003 the day finally came, and I remember vividly how hot it was; and the day went; and people carried on with their business just as before, and have forgotten it completely.
Yet my own view is that we did indeed enter new territory that day; and if we have waited 15 years to get back there (and maybe we will wait still longer), it merely illustrates what we know, that climate change proceeds in a non-linear way, in irregular jumps rather than a smooth ascent. But watch out for it, this sweltering summer (probably in the first week of August); watch out for it on the old-fashioned fahrenheit scale as well as on the modern celsius. And if you see that the ton is up, and 100F is exceeded, be assured that even if a new outright temperature record is not set, the world is changing in the profoundest of ways.
• Michael McCarthy is the author of The Moth Snowstorm: Nature and Joy
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

article_tags: [Climate change, Natural disasters and extreme weather, Environment, World news]
description: From Europe to Africa, extreme and widespread heat raises climate concerns in hottest La Niña year to date on record
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: From Europe to Africa, extreme and widespread heat raises climate concerns in hottest La Niña year to date on record
og_fields.og:title: Heatwave sees record high temperatures around world this week
text:
Record high temperatures have been set across much of the world this week as an unusually prolonged and broad heatwave intensifies concerns about climate change.
The past month has seen power shortages in California as record heat forced a surge of demand for air conditioners. Algeria has experienced the hottest temperature ever reliably registered in Africa. Britain, meanwhile, has experienced its third longest heatwave, melting the roof of a science building in Glasgow and exposing ancient hill forts in Wales. 
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said the rising temperatures were at odds with a global cyclical climate phenomenon known as La Niña, which is usually associated with cooling.
28 June
Glasgow 31.9CBelfast 29.5CDenver, US 40.6C
2 July
Montreal, Canada 36.6CYerevan, Armenia 42C
4 July
Tbilisi, Georgia 40.5C
5 July
Ouargla, Algeria 51.3C
9 July
Tianxiang, Taiwan 40.3C
11 July 
Saih al-Salem 51.4C

“The first six months of the year have made it the hottest La Niña year to date on record,” said Clare Nullis of the WMO.
Taiwan is the most recent place to report a new high with a temperature of 40.3C in Tianxiang on Monday. This followed a flurry of other anomalies.
Last week, a weather station at Ouargla in Algeria’s Sahara Desert, reported a maximum temperature of 51.3C on 5 July, the highest temperature reliably recorded in Africa. 
Even when the sun goes down, night is not providing the cooling relief it once did in many parts of the world. At Quriyat, on the coast of Oman, overnight temperatures remained above 42.6C, which is believed to be the highest “low” temperature ever recorded in the world. Downtown Los Angeles also saw a new monthly July minimum overnight record of 26.1C on 7 July.
Globally, the warmest year on record was in 2016, boosted by the natural climate cycle El Niño. Last year, temperatures hit the highest level without that amplifying phenomenon. This year, at the other cooling end of the cycle, is continuing the overall upward trend.
Swathes of the northern hemisphere have seen unusually persistent warmth due to strong, persistent high pressure systems that have created a “heat dome” over much of Eurasia.
“What’s unusual is the hemispheric scale of the heatwave,” said Michael Mann, director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State University. “It’s not just the magnitude in any one location but that high temperatures are being seen over such a large area.”
Northern Russia’s exceptionally sunny weather – seen on TV by billions thanks to the World Cup – has caused wildfires that affected 80,000 hectares of forest near the Krasnoyarsk region, which reported daily anomalies of 7C above average. The Western Siberian Hydromet Center has issued storm warnings after temperatures of more than 30C for five days. Climate watchers fear this will accelerate the melting of permafrost, releasing methane – a far more potent greenhouse gas than CO2.
In California, daytime records were also set last week at Chino (48.9C), Burbank airport (45.6C) and Van Nuys airport (47.2C). In Canada, at least 54 deaths have been attributed to the prolonged heatwave and high humidity in Quebec. Montreal saw a new record high temperature of 36.6C on 2 July.
In Europe, the WMO has warned of droughts, wildfires and harvest losses after the second hottest June on record. Over the past two weeks, records have been set in Tbilisi (40.5C), Shannon (32C), and Belfast (29.5C) 
Britain has cooled slightly in the past two days, after 17 days of temperatures over 28C. This was the third longest heatwave on record, following the record 19-day run in 2013 and the famous summer of 1976, when there were two prolonged spells of 18 days and 15 days. Dean Hall of the UK’s Met Office said Britain’s temperatures were forecast to rise again over the coming week.
The concern is that weather fronts – hot and cold – are being blocked more frequently due to climate change. This causes droughts and storms to linger, amplifying the damage they cause. This was a factor in the recent devastating floods in Japan, where at least 150 people died after rainfall up to four times the normal level.
Paolo Ruti of the WMO said it was difficult to ascribe any one weather event to climate change, but that recent high temperatures, intense rains and slow-moving fronts were in line with forecasts of how rising emissions will affect the climate.
“Recent analysis suggests that anthropogenic forcing might indeed affect the characteristics of summer blocking events in the Euro-Asia sector, in particular leading to longer blocking episodes,” he said. 
Extreme weather events have buffeted much of the world over the past 12months, from the “Day Zero” drought in Cape Town to the abnormally powerful hurricanes Harvey and Irma that buffeted the east coast of the US and Caribbean. 
 Underscoring the link, a new report from scientists at the World Weather Attribution group indicates that manmade climate change and its effect on rainfall made the recent Cape Town drought three times more likely.
… we have a small favour to ask. More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

It was incredibly selfish... unless you are going to ensure he is absolutely loaded.
Climate change will take a while to affect much of humanity but the first people to suffer will be the poor. Firstly, there will be large regions of Africa, India and the Middle East, as well as Central America and parts of Asia that will become uninhabitable for ordinary folk.
The solution for these people is simple, and we even see that solution today. Migration. They will move to cooler climes. 
So, expect mass migration on an unprecedented scale into places like Northern Europe, northern China, Central Asia.
But here’s the good bit. Rich people don’t suffer from mass migration. In crime ridden cities they have homes in fenced off areas, police forces and private security to protect them. Meanwhile, there are lots of places in the countryside where economic activity is low but where rich people live, so there’s little crime in those areas.
Some good friends of mine have started using their bonuses and profit they’ve made on their London properties to buy second homes. Currently they rent these out but the idea is that one day their infant children will be able to move into them.
London might be overwhelmed with people from the Third World in a couple of decades time, but my friends’ children will by then be well set up young adults with homes of their own and bright futures ahead of them.
So, just get rich and your child will be able to ward off the effects of climate change probably for life.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531587627000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17480038', u'in_reply_to': u'118274403', u'id': u'118274906', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dholliday', u'text': u'BQSTART

China's industrialization has used only a fraction of the time period enjoyed by countries such as Britain. Regardless, you can't compare China to the UK: China has a huge population, huge economy and are manufacturing a massive amount of stuff that used to be manufactured by Western countries but is no longer - but is of course still enjoyed and consumed by them.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531583306000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16765789', u'in_reply_to': u'118272039', u'id': u'118272306', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"Prolonged sunshine now seems ominous"
As we watch CO2 accumulating faster and faster in the atmosphere we might ask where we are now, long before feeling the full effects of a rise in temperature of just over 1 degree C, due to lags in the system.
We’ve been seeing numerous impacts catching many scientists by surprise with how soon they are occurring. In 2014 two independent teams of scientists reported that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is likely irreversibly retreating. 3.3 meters of sea level rise equivalent of ice there is being destabilized by warming oceans and energy is going into the net melting of ice all over the planet. 
The paleoclimate record shows that increasing global temperature by just 1.5-2 degrees C above preindustrial temperature commits the system to an eventual 6-9m of sea level rise, a large fraction of which could arrive within the next 100 years.
Corals may not survive this century of warming and acidifying oceans, and droughts and floods linked to global warming—and conflict linked to those droughts—have already caused four countries to face famine.
Because of the decades to millennial long lag between a climate forcing and our feeling the effect, due to the thermal inertia of the ocean and response time of the ice sheets, the effects we are feeling now are largely just the beginning of the result of emissions from the 20th century. And emissions have been increasing steadily for decades.
We are also seeing numerous amplifying feedbacks: loss of albedo (heat reflectivity) from ice melt, permafrost melt, methane release and massive wildfires; the Earth is starting to wrest any possible further human control of the climate away.
We're about out of time on this, if not already, and leaders are not only still acting as if this is not a planetary emergency, but some are acting as if there isn’t a problem at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531583294000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'lags in the system', u'effect': u'as watch we might ask where we are now long before feeling the full effects of a rise in temperature of just over 1 degree c'}, {u'cause': u'the thermal inertia of the ocean and response time of the ice sheets', u'effect': u'our feeling the effect'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'118272303', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VeryInterestingTimes', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

I fret about the fact that the bees are less in number than a few weeks ago and wildlife is suffering. I fret about the lack of grazing for sheep and cattle.
Enjoy your summer (Personally, I'd like a few degrees cooler and some rain soon) Even were this just a long, hot summer rather than evidence of climate change I'd cut back on the ice lollies, we might need to save some pennies for higher food prices this winter.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531583080000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4186778', u'in_reply_to': u'118263037', u'id': u'118272260', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'BQSTART
A review of climate change literature between 1965 and 1979, undertaken in 2008, found that 44 papers "predicted, implied, or provided supporting evidence" for global warming, while only seven did so for global cooling. 
"Global cooling was never more than a minor aspect of the scientific climate change literature of the era, let alone the scientific consensus..." the reviewers remarked.

description: 1955, 1976 and 2018 – the weeks of sun that were once an innocent pleasure, I now see as climate change, says Guardian columnist Ian Jack
og_fields.og:description: 1955, 1976 and 2018 – the weeks of sun that were once an innocent pleasure, I now see as climate change, says Guardian columnist Ian Jack
og_fields.og:title: This, the third great summer of my lifetime, feels ominous | Ian Jack
text:
The sun shone and shone over County Cork last week, just as it did over most of Britain. When we came last year, to the same place in the same week, the steep banks of the lanes grew thick with wild roses, fuchsia and foxgloves; now the vegetation looked limper and dustier, the roses drier, the foxgloves solitary and stooped. But a poorer foreground view had its compensation in the background, where the lack of drizzle, cloud and mist revealed a rolling landscape of hills and woods that was unexpectedly Tuscan in its clarity. By four in the afternoon, the airless main streets of the small towns felt like ovens.
On the coast east of Skibbereen we found a delightful cove, of the sort that in my experience rarely exists outside children’s fiction: perfect in its firm sand, its protective reefs of smooth black rock, and its warren of caves that ran back into the cliffs, invaded every day by the tide, and entirely free of plastic flotsam. The sea was calm and clear, and changed its shade of blue according to the depth and composition of the seabed. Moreover, it wasn’t chill. In 60-odd years swimming off the British coastline, I’ve rarely known water as welcoming or as hard to leave: even after 40 minutes, it seemed a shame to get out.
Newspaper reports said the prolonged heatwave had raised sea temperatures in other places to over 20C, which sounded impossibly warm, almost like a heated swimming pool. In that temperature, there would surely be no dallying in the shallows, no theatrical shivering when the water reached crotch level, no complaining that the cold was unbearable, no need to stand there uncertainly while your companion, already swimming briskly, urged you to “get in and get it over with”. Instead immersion would be a swift, Mediterranean experience – a run or brisk walk into the sea and then a splash as you struck out for the diving platform.
Temperatures in the Firth of Forth never made getting into the water so easy. To be consistently tempting, the estuary needed exceptional conditions – and the summer of 1955 provided them. The sun shone for weeks, and day after day my friends and I made the 10-minute walk to the beach – not a Blue Flag candidate, if Blue Flags had existed then, because a pipe ran right down the middle of it that carried sewage to the sea from the army barracks to the rear.
Looking back, it seems odd that people made no fuss about this, or about another more torrential outlet not far upstream, where the sewage turned the sea pink with its infusions of potassium permanganate. But it was a beach, all the same, with a sandbank that appeared at low tide and a hut at the far end that opened on especially busy days to sell crisps and lemonade; and by the second week, I had taught myself to swim.
All kinds of things happened in 1955: Anthony Eden won the general election; Princess Margaret announced that she didn’t intend to marry RAF Group Captain Peter Townsend; Ruth Ellis became the last woman to be hanged in the UK. I remember none of them. For me, it was the year I was turned brown by the sun.
A family snapshot, one of our first in colour, shows me in swimming trunks, staring across a shiny flat sea towards a visiting American battleship, the USS Wisconsin, which lay anchored in the firth. My back is unselfconsciously brown – there had been no lying on towels and striving for this effect – which tells a story of capering about on the beach with no recourse to the plastic macs and sweaters that in most years the visitor to the Scottish seaside was wise to bring. (As the actor and comedian Stanley Baxter remembers, returned Glaswegian holidaymakers when questioned about the weather might reply stoically, “Well, it never kept us in.”)
The strong sunlight gave everything a memorable clarity, just as it did in Ireland last week, so that certain scenes of no particular emotional importance remain fixed, when in other years they would have faded: the sight of a spoil tip near an old mine or ironworks – abandoned even in 1955 – that revealed an interior of bright red cinders where a jagged crack had split its grassy surface. It makes no sense to remember it, and yet there it is through the window of the Glasgow bus, under a bright blue sky.
Unclothed adults at the seaside were then hardly visible, other than in newspaper pictures of crowded beaches at sophisticated resorts such as Ayr or Blackpool. When my grandfathers came to the beach, they retained their flat caps and waistcoats. My mother never owned a swimsuit. My father had trunks – as a boy he’d liked to swim – but I only once saw him wear them. None of this was very exceptional. I can’t think of any adult in our street who went to the beach and did much more than roll up a trouser leg.
Nobody could have complained, as the aesthete James Lees-Milne did in his diary in July 1976: “Heatwave continuing. Whole country parched, and trees dying. Found E naked but for a pair of long blue shorts, with white skin, smarmed hair (for he had just had a bath), flabby muscles, pendulous breasts, looking like Picasso aged 90. How can aesthetic persons bear to be seen in this condition at 74 even by their intimates?”
The great summers of my lifetime have been 1955, 1976 and now this one. With each, a little more innocence has been shed as well as clothes. Prolonged sunshine now seems ominous – a portent as well as a pleasure. Ireland, for instance, has a rural economy that largely depends on grass, and in a drought grass fails to thrive. That has huge consequences for every cattle farmer, but posterity may see it as no more than a little local difficulty, one of the negligible effects of a global temperature change that melts glaciers and ice caps. Carpe diem, then, in a cove near Skibbereen.
• Ian Jack is a Guardian columnist
… in the fight to protect the environment. By keeping the Guardian’s environmental coverage open and accessible, we can report on the changes needed to avoid climate and natural catastrophe. The choices made by individuals are important, but we need to work together for the systemic transformation that will make a real difference. As well as reporting the facts about what is happening now, we investigate the causes and talk to the people trying to make the future better. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

Corn ethanol is even worse all that harvesting and processing is $1 in and $1-$2 out.Back in 2008 the oil companies tried to sell the oil at the price it used to cost which was $140 a barrel- but the economy was not happy about that, across the world the economy was built on $40 a barrel oil.After the oil crash a couple of years back the frackers avoided marginal fields and cut costs, and in the wider economy made a lot of efficacy savings particularly delivering things from the factory- but these were one off savings: The smart wildcatters got better at spotting better locations and the only route for the economy to make savings is to cut down on the fuel bill [with cheaper electricity for transport] and to swap workers for robots.And oil [and coal] will continue to get a little bit more expensive each time it is drilled for.The fix is the same fix that business used to get poorer workers who had their jobs exported to China to continue buying products, and the same fix that people use when their wages go down..... cheap easy debt.Back in the 70s debt was a means to expand- something that produced assets, now it is an almost permanent situation. For the oil industry it is constant [the big oil companies have some leeway and raise cash].The government is actively keeping debt cheap and Trump is actively making a law to make utilities buy coal. Not very free market.If interest rates go up- which is good for the lenders [and savers] then fracking oil businesses will go down, an if they go down their importance means that some of the economy followers them. Your taxes already prop up US coal- your taxes pay for mines to be cleaned up, for miners medicare to be met, for the cost of pollution- and at some point US oil will be uneconomic - not because it is not useful but simply because the economy cannot pay its true cost of $140 a barrel.
And that does not include the cost of AGW [which you don't accept]- now you may join with the government and believe that oil and coal are of national importance like the military and like the military should be funded with tax payers money. But this all sounds very left wing like Venezuela and its nationalised oil.You may want oil and coal to last forever but it won't- it could last much longer if the economy was prepared to pay far more for it, but it can't.Alternative energy is now as good as fossil fuels- and it will get cheaper, where as oil and coal can only get more expensive. Alternative energy is the free market choice in a perfectly free market [but not when they are being bailed by government and the banks who will come to the govt to get bailed out].
So if it were Blockbuster hanging on and Netflixs was on the rise the smart thing would have been for Blockbuster to switch its business model- not to borrow more money and for the government to actively make DVD rental cheaper than streaming.A carbon [dioxide] tax is a smart way to make the free market more free [and not give fossil fuels an upper hand] and a means to make sure that the economy is not wreaked and that the switch is smooth.If you have a better idea do say.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531992617000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'simply the economy can not pay its true cost of $ 140 a barrel', u'effect': u'because it is not useful but'}, {u'cause': u'it is not useful but simply because the economy can not pay its true cost of $ 140 a barrel', u'effect': u'at some point us oil will be uneconomic not'}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'118445985', u'id': u'118473300', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'And the post I was responding too.

BQSTART
A horse required ten times as much food as the average soldier. During the First World War, there was a distinct lack of grass for them eat on the Western Front or in the deserts of the Middle East. This meant that horse fodder was the largest commodity shipped to the front by many of the participating nations.
BQEND
https://www.nam.ac.uk/explore/british-army-horses-during-first-world-war
The source is not perfect but the data is about there.
Worth noting the come back will be some waffle about less humans cost less. Trained workers able to use machines cost more than manual labourers or at least did in the early industrial era. 
This is a complex topic, fascinating but not one for people so limited they think animals a "free" for farmers or that coal replaced slaves in agriculture.

on the grounds that some people disagree with you,

I said as much here:
BQSTART

description: Dana Nuccitelli: But global warming will.
headline: d
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: But global warming will.
og_fields.og:title: Comprehensive study: carbon taxes won't hamper the economy | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Eleven teams participated in a recent Stanford Energy Modeling Forum (EMF) project, examining the economic and environmental impacts of a carbon tax. The studies included “revenue recycling,” in which the funds generated from a carbon tax are returned to taxpayers either through regular household rebate checks (similar to the Citizens’ Climate Lobby [CCL] and Climate Leadership Council [CLC] proposals) or by offsetting income taxes (similar to the approach in British Columbia).
Among the eleven modeling teams the key findings were consistent. First, a carbon tax is effective at reducing carbon pollution, although the structure of the tax (the price and the rate at which it rises) are important. Second, this type of revenue-neutral carbon tax would have a very modest impact on the economy in terms of gross domestic product (GDP). In all likelihood it would slightly slow economic growth, but by an amount that would be more than offset by the benefits of cutting pollution and slowing global warming.
Meanwhile, House Republicans are again on the verge of introducing a Resolution denouncing a carbon tax as “detrimental to American families and businesses, and is not in the best interest of the United States.”
The modeling teams examined four carbon tax scenarios, with starting prices of $25 or $50 per ton of carbon dioxide, rising at 1% or 5% per year. These are somewhat modest policy scenarios; CCL proposes a starting tax of $15 per ton rising at $10 per year, and the CLC proposes $40 per ton rising around 4% per year. The most aggressive policy considered by the Stanford EMF teams ($50 per ton rising 5% per year) falls in between these two proposals.
The modeling studies consistently found that for all four carbon tax policies considered, whether the revenue is returned via rebate checks or by offsetting income taxes, the direct economic impact is minimal:
in every policy scenario, in every model, the U.S. economy continues to grow at or near its long-term average baseline rate, deviating from reference growth by no more than about 0.1% points. We find robust evidence that even the most ambitious carbon tax is consistent with long-term positive economic growth, near baseline rates, not even counting the growth benefits of a less-disrupted climate or lower ambient air pollution
The last sentence is critical. The analyses consistently found that coal power plants would be the biggest losers if a carbon tax were implemented, and the costs associated with health impacts from other pollutants released by burning coal (e.g. soot and mercury) are substantial. Phasing out coal power plants results in significant health and economic benefits to society. 
So does slowing global warming, of course. A working paper recently published by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond concluded that US economic growth would slow by an extra 0.2–0.5% per year if we stay on our current climate path (3–3.5°C global warming) than if we meet the 2°C Paris target. This compares favorably to a less than 0.1% per year slowing of the US economic growth rate under the carbon tax scenarios.
In short, climate change will slow American economic growth. If we don’t curb global warming, the economic impact will be larger. If we implement a carbon tax to help meet the Paris climate targets, the economic impact will be negligible, and will be offset by the benefits of phasing out dirty coal power plants.
The Stanford EMF studies also consistently concluded that a carbon tax is an effective way to curb carbon pollution, especially in the power sector:
carbon price scenarios lead to significant reductions in CO2 emissions, with the vast majority of the reductions occurring in the electricity sector and disproportionately through reductions in coal … Expected economic costs (not accounting for any of the benefits of GHG and conventional pollutant mitigation), in terms of either GDP or welfare, are modest
The analyses also found that the rate of increase of the carbon tax was more important than the starting price. For example, a tax of $50 per ton of carbon dioxide rising by 5% per year would cut carbon pollution 33–56% by 2040. A tax of $25 per ton rising 5% per year cuts it by 25–50% by 2040. However, the policies including a tax increasing at just 1% per year would result in a short-term cut (of about 20–40%), but carbon pollution would remain stable at those levels. 
These results suggest that the most effective carbon tax might start relatively low to give taxpayers time to adjust, but increase rapidly over time, similar to the CCL proposal, which a separate report projected to cut carbon pollution 52% by 2040. The Stanford EMF studies also found that returning the tax revenue by offsetting income taxes was slightly more beneficial for the economy than using dividend checks as the rebate mechanism, but the former is a regressive policy and the latter is progressive.
Real-world examples demonstrate that pricing carbon pollution is smart. British Columbia’s emissions have fallen as its economy has continued to grow. California’s carbon cap and trade system has helped the state meet its climate targets 4 years ahead of schedule, while its economy has flourished.
NEWS RELEASE: Climate pollutants fall below 1990 levels for first time ➡️ https://t.co/8FaHsL8rXD #AB32 #SB32Achievement roughly equal to taking 12 million cars off the road or saving 6 billion gallons of gasoline a year #ActOnClimate pic.twitter.com/bVRCGpX4vh
Economic analyses consistently show that cutting carbon pollution will benefit the economy, and that a revenue-neutral carbon tax is an efficient way of accomplishing that goal. That’s why there’s a 95% consensus among economists that the US government should commit to cutting carbon pollution, with 81% favoring a market-based solution like a carbon tax.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

[{u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'In Australia the megafauna took 30,000 to 40,000 years to disappear after people arrived.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532055826000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'118421477', u'id': u'118507763', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Morat', u'text': u'Hmmm."Overpopulation may actually be an entirely natural process " Like with lemmings, and our cliff, of course is the planet burning up?
"we have achieved the ability to master our environment" Roflfho. Do you work for the US EPA?
Just where have you been living the last 20 years to even start to believe that?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532034056000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2502555', u'in_reply_to': u'118421766', u'id': u'118503650', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'minesboggled', u'text': u'Our ridiculous lifestyles - based almost exclusively on consumerism now - are promoted by corporate marketing and profiteering. Dismantle the corporations - at least to a size where they no longer represent a threat - and most problems would be solved. Corporations now represent a new wave of profiteering imperialism, scavenging what little is left.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531982901000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100481637', u'id': u'118467175', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'minesboggled', u'text': u'Indigenous peoples have a different relationship with the environment - they understand how much they depend on it. I'm confident local ecosystems are better off in their hands. At least give them a majority say in the matter. They should have rights to claim ownership too. That includes the local resources. We certainly have no rights over them, even if local officials are bribed by global corporations. Perhaps it's time we dismantled corporations - piece by piece - until we're satisfied they're no longer big enough to be a threat.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531982198000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100481637', u'in_reply_to': u'118367474', u'id': u'118466934', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'Hey Eric, it is possible that North American megafuna was not wiped out by people. A comet impact on the ice sheet then covering Canada may have caused a giant flood of meltwater and also a "nuclear winter" that started the Younger Dryas. The flood waters would have shut down the gulfstream.http://www.iflscience.com/environment/did-a-comet-impact-cause-massive-wildfires-that-extended-the-ice-age/', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531928069000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a comet impact on the ice sheet then covering canada', u'effect': u'a giant flood of meltwater and also a winter'}], u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'118421477', u'id': u'118447570', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zuftawov943', u'text': u'It's a good thing when it is controlled by people who know how to apply and limit it, who burn a patch of forest, on a part of their territory and perhaps between two rivers, grow a crop and then leave the patch be for years while the forest re-asserts itself. 
There are indigenous peoples who respect and manage their territory well, as well as those who make a mess of it. In South America, the distractions of the intrusive, outside world - such as alcohol, prostitution and trinkets - can cause damage to, even obliteration of, entire mini-nations, some of which comprise barely a hundred people. However, it is remarkable how successful many such tribal peoples are, despite the assaults on their ways, on their very existence.
Meanwhile, elsewhere in this parish today, a story about Trump insisting that his father was born in Germany has attracted more than 2,300 postings below the line, while this important report has, as I write, fewer than 20. Priorities, you are fled and tattered.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531914579000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the distractions of the intrusive world', u'effect': u'damage to'}], u'author_id': u'11457447', u'in_reply_to': u'118396813', u'id': u'118434932', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'1ntelligentDesign', u'text': u'The debate about whether or not Homo sapiens are J-Curve or S-Curve species is ongoing...time will tell. Overpopulation may actually be an entirely natural process as we have achieved the ability to master our environment, improve our chances of survival, and minimise risk. The fact is the idea that we as a species are demonstrating supreme resourcefulness to safeguard a typical individual is indeed "natural" is not only plausible, but reasonable too. 
Now, is overpopulation desirable - of course not.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531893979000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15915161', u'in_reply_to': u'118393856', u'id': u'118421766', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Tell that to the woolly mammoths, mastodons, giant sloths, saber tooth tigers, etc which tended to disappear whenever our hunter-gatherer ancestors showed up.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531892619000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'118393784', u'id': u'118421477', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'32123', u'text': u'when the majority of the world's population have the basic socio-economic security needed not to have to worry about old age/illness survival, they will stop having the large numbers of children they do as insurance/pension.and there are somewhere close to a billion people on the planet whose carbon footprints are many times the rest of the population. why should the poor cut back on their security while the well-off moralise? it's all a bit victorian.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531873833000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2031825', u'in_reply_to': u'118370071', u'id': u'118419646', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'32123', u'text': u'time to harvest all that karma?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531873398000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2031825', u'in_reply_to': u'118393856', u'id': u'118419607', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Denis la Minaccia', u'text': u'Spot on! 
I'm especially baffled by a complaint that indigenous people are banned from "traditional forest management using controlled burning". In what way a forest burning is a good thing? Only because something is "traditional", doesn't mean it has to be tolerated.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531835098000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'only something is traditional', u'effect': u"does n't mean it has to be tolerated"}], u'author_id': u'10416427', u'in_reply_to': u'118367474', u'id': u'118396813', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Reduce the unnatural overpopulation.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531831888000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'118393856', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Those who live peacefully with their environment should be listened to. The boorish consumers have treated them appallingly for too long, now let them speak and let us try to understand what they say. Please', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531831823000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'118393784', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pazmino', u'text': u'There's more information about how tribal peoples make the best conservationists, incl. ways to help, here: https://www.survivalinternational.org/conservation', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531823347000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1980391', u'id': u'118385491', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MrPolitics', u'text': u'Well the rights of the indigenous people should be protected no matter what natural resources we in the industrialised world want to take from their lands. 
Of course the Guardian has covered the subject before but if you really want to save the environment on the planet so that us humans curb the damage they are creating in the Anthropocene, then we have to start reducing our human numbers. 
The growth in humanity is the issue that effects all environmental issues. Until we reduce our numbers we will not solve the issues around environmental damage which effects us and other species. 
More worrying is that it might be too late as we are slow to change our ways as a species and with ice caps melting the release of CO2 into the ozone will create temperature rises that the majority of life on earth won't be able to survive. 
The scary thing is that human extinction might not be far off. Literally between 9 and 100 years depending on which alarmist scientist you listen to. Do you think I am exaggerating? Let me know if you do and I will go into more detail. But as good Guardian readers I will presume you all know we're doomed and your already planning on moving to higher ground to try and survive a few months longer.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531782035000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3602670', u'id': u'118370071', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'uncommodified', u'text': u'Indigenous rights and environmental protection are both very important but they are not the same thing. Local people the world over should have a much much greater say in what kind of economic development is allowed to take place in their areas, so that they can protect their community and their way of life. That should be true of indigenous tribes just as much as long established communities in the developed world.
The environment should be protected for its own sake. There should be largely natural areas that are reserved for indigenous/local groups to use for fishing, gathering etc etc and on top of this there should be areas that are totally proscribed from exploitation. We NEED more areas like this if our ecosystems are to recover from the apocalypse we are inflicting on them. Those areas can and should be administered or policed by local indigenous groups though', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531775952000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18309811', u'id': u'118367669', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'witness67', u'text': u'Absolutely disagree. This is racist & does not take into account that indigenous people can be corrupted as much as any other race. I know of plenty of examples in Australia where indigenous people have been handed massive areas of land and within weeks they've signed off on logging/mining/tourism contracts. In many cases they must have been in negotiations whilst the land rights were being sorted out in court, it happened so quickly. We can't trust them to do the right thing by the environment & why should we. They are human. The world is in peril and to entrust one subset of people with conservation on the the basis of race is fraught with problems.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531775343000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13146319', u'id': u'118367474', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Glenister', u'text': u'Come on G 300 hundred ? Try three hundred.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531768166000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12612720', u'in_reply_to': u'118364109', u'id': u'118364500', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Glenister', u'text': u'"Rights" is a minefield. A right is a man-made thing and it's to man it should refer. To say "that tree has a perfect right to be there" is misleading. The tree's there and the issue is whether any person has the right to harm utilize interfere nurture. Probably the basis should be to leave alone unless man's well-being requires otherwise - a difficult balancing act because it's not always clear what's harmful. 300 hundred years ago burning coal was thought harmless but now we have James Hansen blaming the UK for causing major pollution then and ever since.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531767345000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it 's not always clear what 's harmful", u'effect': u"unless man 's well being requires otherwise a difficult balancing act"}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'major pollution'}], u'author_id': u'12612720', u'id': u'118364109', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'It's only the key because human rights are taken slightly more serious than the environment and other living beings. That doesn't make the conservation argument weak, it's just a lack of empathy, or even more often a complete lack of empathy among politicians and the fossil fuel and mono-agri business sectors.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531757843000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'human rights are taken slightly more serious than the environment and other living beings', u'effect': u"it 's only the key"}], u'author_id': u'17632173', u'id': u'118357244', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}]
description: David Hill: Special Rapporteur on indigenous peoples calls for a new, rights-based approach to conservation
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: David Hill: Special Rapporteur on indigenous peoples calls for a new, rights-based approach to conservation
og_fields.og:title: Rights not 'fortress conservation' key to save planet, says UN expert
text:
The United Nations Special Rapporteur on indigenous peoples, Victoria Tauli-Corpuz, has released a report highly critical of the global conservation movement and calling for indigenous peoples and other local communities to have a greater say in protecting the world’s forests. Titled Cornered by Protected Areas and co-authored with the US-based NGO Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI), the report is an explicit condemnation of “fortress conservation.”
What exactly is meant by that? It is “the idea that to protect forests and biodiversity, ecosystems need to function in isolation, devoid of people,” the Rapporteur told the Guardian. “This model - favoured by governments for over a century - ignores the growing body of evidence that forests thrive when Indigenous Peoples remain on their customary lands and have legally recognised rights to manage and protect them.”
The report effectively consists of an open letter by the Rapporteur, a brief by her and two former RRI employees, and five case-studies on India, Indonesia, Panama, Peru and the Republic of the Congo written by other researchers. It was made public during the recent Oslo Tropical Forest Forum. Here are 10 of the most fascinating take-aways:
1 Vast areas. The global network of “protected areas” such as national parks expanded by 80% between 1970 and 1985 - the majority in so-called “developing” countries - and today they cover 15% of global land surface excluding Antarctica. Expanding the network is integral to meeting the aims of the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Such areas are seen as a fundamental way of combatting anthropomorphic climate change and protecting the world’s forests, biodiversity and ecosystems.
2 Devastating impacts. Huge areas of indigenous peoples’ and other local communities’ land have been overlapped by “protected areas”, according to the Rapporteur, and the impacts are alleged to have been devastating. They include an estimated 250,000 people forcibly evicted from their homes and land between 1990 and 2014 according to one study, houses burnt down, access to land and important sites denied, extrajudicial killings, social conflict, access to justice obstructed, and food sovereignty eroded by bans on subsistence hunting and the “vilification” and “criminalisation” of “slash-and-burn” agriculture. “Protected areas” have caused - and continue to cause - “chronic patterns of abuse” and “large-scale human rights violations.”
3 Lots of words, little action. Despite commitments by “the world’s most influential conservation organisations” to respect indigenous peoples and other local communities’ rights, it is argued that “little has changed” in practice over the last 14 years. Which conservation organisations exactly? The Rapporteur doesn’t say, but she footnotes a 2014 report summarising commitments made by Birdlife, Conservation International, Fauna and Flora International, International Union for the Conservation of Nature, The Nature Conservancy, the Wildlife Conservation Society and the World Wide Fund for Nature.
4 Local peoples’ contributions. Indigenous peoples and other local communities are described as “effective biodiversity and conservation managers”, and the “primary custodians of most of the world’s remaining tropical forests and biodiversity hotspots.” Tree cover loss is reported to be less than half on land that is indigenous- and/or community-run when compared to elsewhere, and when rights to own their land are legally recognised “the difference is even greater.”
5 Not enough rights or money. Despite such contributions, the Rapporteur argues that there has been “no or limited recognition of rights” and that indigenous peoples and local communities receive “only a small percentage” of official “protected areas” funding, which is roughly estimated at $6-6.5 billion a year and called “consistently inadequate.” However, indigenous peoples and other local communities themselves are reported to be “substantial investors”, and represent better value for money than official conservation funding by achieving “at least equal results with a fraction of the budget.”
6 Tigers v tribes. The India case-study focuses on tiger reserves - reportedly comprising 50 of 617 “protected areas’” but capturing 70% of the national conservation budget - and one in particular now called the Biligiri Rangaswamy Temple Tiger Reserve. Many people - mostly Soliga adivasi - have been forcibly relocated, denied access to land and important sites, and banned from hunting, “shifting cultivation” agriculture and traditional forest management using controlled burning. There was some good news in 2011 when 32 Soliga settlements were granted rights under the 2006 Forest Rights Act - reportedly India’s first case of rights being given to a community in a protected area under that law - and another 10 communities were granted rights earlier this year, but financial and state support for community-run conservation “has not been forthcoming.” Some settlements still face relocation.
7 Indigenous peoples in “isolation.” The Peru case-study focuses on the Manu National Park in the Amazon where the situation is made even more complicated by the presence of indigenous peoples living in “isolation” or “initial contact.” Despite some advances, a system to protect them is reportedly “yet to be developed”, while four “stable” - effectively “contacted” - indigenous communities remain without title to their land and have had their collective rights “infringed upon.” The park was established “on the basis it would be inviolable and free of human interference”, but the heart of it was - and remains - indigenous territory.
8 Connection to nature. One point emerging from the report is the importance of their land to indigenous peoples and other local communities. This is emphasised in the case-studies on Indonesia, which describes forests as “forming the basis” of indigenous peoples’ “existence and identities”, and India, which describes the landscape in the tiger reserve as “alive with meaning and connection” for the Soliga - “none of which is recognised by protectionist conservation.” The Rapporteur puts it like this: “In indigenous worldviews people are seen largely as intrinsic parts of nature rather than as distinct and separate from it,” and “many share an ethical interconnection with nature through their languages, beliefs, and practices” which reflects “a commitment to respecting and caring for the natural world.”
9 Culture clash. Another point that emerges is how indigenous peoples’ and other local communities’ worldviews differ to that of governments and the global conservation movement. The India case-study reports that the Soliga think a “good” forest means an “open-canopy savanna woodland”, but for the government and conservationists the “ideal condition” is a “closed forest.” In the Indonesia case-study, one Kasepuhan leader is quoted as saying: “conservation has different meanings for people with or without education. For local people, we are doing conservation, we are taking responsibility for what is alive and what has died. But for people with education, conservation means that we do not do anything: when forest is green, people can only look at it.”
10 What to do - now and urgently. All the case-studies make country-specific recommendations, but the Rapporteur’s brief issues a rallying-cry to “take down the wall of fortress conservation” and calls for a “new approach” to conservation in general. It lists four things that urgently need doing now: 1) create a global “monitoring and grievance mechanism; 2) establish national “accountability and reparation mechanisms”; 3) ensure the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples is fully integrated into all future conservation and climate change mitigation measures; and 4) spend more conservation finance on “community-run conservation initiatives” based around an “emerging suite of approaches such as co-management, indigenous-managed protected areas, and indigenous territorial governance.”
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for humanity and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

One of the scientists who helped write that report produced a computer model of the effect of CO2 on surface temperatures in 1974 which predicted the warming seen by 2015.The Charney Report 1979 is still used as a bench mark for climate sensitivity to CO2.
By their actions it is now a provable historical fact the ruling class do not give a shit about the effects of climate change produced by the burning of CO2 and never will.', u'recommendation_count': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ethan Hawkins', u'text': u'These problems are already solved in a wide variety of ways.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532036156000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17811466', u'in_reply_to': u'118417647', u'id': u'118504231', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ethan Hawkins', u'text': u'For technical clarification: the current von Neumann architecture has at least two MASSIVE points ripe for optimization which could drop power consumption by an order of magnitude or more:
1. The low-hanging fruit is that around 20-30% of all power consumed on a chip has to do with the clock pulse. With smarter software tools, clock synchronization can be eliminated. We already know how to do this. What's stopping this is 100% business considerations (like lack of demand and how do you market something that doesn't have a GHz rating) and nothing to do with technology. Appropriately high carbon taxation of data centers would put this technology on the front burner again.
2. A lot of the remaining power consumption has to do with memory architecture and "bus" access (both on and off the chip). Blurring the lines between memory and processor (to the point where computers don't have processors per se) has the potential to reduce this inefficiency to near zero while massively increasing parallel compute power. Instead of measuring computers in GHz and processors, it would be measured in something closer to digital neurons, each of which has pervasive and highly localized storage and compute power. This is likely closer to how the brain works. What we're doing right now is basically insane if heat is an issue.
I really do see no reason that more than 90% of the power currently consumed by chips can't be eliminated. The upper bound is probably closer to 99% as it seems likely that 99% of the distance that electrons travel on a chip right now is pure waste due to our limited intellectual ability to organize chips. Don't get me wrong, von Neumann was one of the great geniuses of all time, but his ideas are rapidly running out of steam.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532035823000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'our limited intellectual ability to organize chips', u'effect': u'that 99 % of the distance that electrons travel on a chip right now is pure waste'}], u'author_id': u'17811466', u'in_reply_to': u'118503821', u'id': u'118504135', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ethan Hawkins', u'text': u'One huge difference between information and aviation is that, based on the laws of physics, aviation is always going to consume massive amounts of power. This is not necessarily true of data technologies. Looking back, the power consumption of Eniac was absolutely massive on a per-bit basis, but vacuum tubes gave way to integrated circuits, which gave way to photolithography, which will eventually give way to 3D storage and clockless chips. In the not very distant future, we can eventually expect entire server farms consuming megawatts to disappear into volumes smaller than a laptop and with similar power consumption. The main reason this hasn't happened already is not technological. So, yes, this is a problem, for now. But it's not going to remain a problem forever and we can address this issue in ways that the aviation industry simply could never. Furthermore, the power going into shipping bits around partly comes out of the power that WAS used to ship the equivalent paper (or people!) around. It's not at all clear that this digital world is less efficient. It seems to me that it's quite probably a lot MORE efficient than the way we used to do things in a great many cases (a Skype call versus a plane trip, an Amazon order fulfilled by a central warehouse versus driving to six different stores). Before we get all upset about this, I think someone would need to do a really detailed analysis of the pros and cons. And in any case, while there's huge room for improvement, we won't be going backwards anytime soon. Why? Because the data world is a lot more efficient than the real one.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532034764000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17811466', u'id': u'118503821', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BullShizer', u'text': u'Look at this piece of news also and it's just one company admitting to burning excess stock; what a flipping waste!https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-44885983', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532029346000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14163149', u'in_reply_to': u'118420051', u'id': u'118502275', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nosheds', u'text': u'So, to summarise - your position is that if someone states that maybe it's time to lower the birthrate they should then top themselves? It seems that your age came without wisdom.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532021174000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16349429', u'in_reply_to': u'118485096', u'id': u'118497999', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ricardo20000', u'text': u'Bitcoin represents the heart and soul of modern conservative capitalism and libertarian philosophy: empty promises built on soulless greed.Streaming video represents the heart of modern society: vapid spectacle next to indifference for the real world.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532014477000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14391570', u'in_reply_to': u'118377195', u'id': u'118493433', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Marty_m', u'text': u'Good point.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532009180000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15851692', u'in_reply_to': u'118397409', u'id': u'118489782', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MrEurope', u'text': u'Old enough to understand that advocating less people on the planet is by definition and unavoidably a hypocritical position unless followed by suicide or an admission that the person stating such belief deems himself more worthy than those who should not be.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532004640000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4158374', u'in_reply_to': u'118412230', u'id': u'118485096', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Steve__M', u'text': u'I think you are right that the article writer should have been a bit clearer. But Greenpeace have always been consistent. Nuclear is very safe, but when it goes wrong it goes very wrong indeed. The impact on the UK of an accident would be high in part because many of the power stations are close to big towns and key transport routes.
I do think that the cost of Hinkley C is skewing the choices being made about our energy infrastructure.
If electricity prices fall much below the guaranteed Hinkley C cost, some people will start to go off-grid to avoid being forced to pay for it causing it to be even more expensive for everyone else.
To avoid that happening, the government will be looking to prevent electricity prices falling too far by restricting alternatives such as the tidal lagoon plans.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531995806000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'many of the power stations are close to big towns and key transport routes', u'effect': u'the impact on the uk of an accident would be high in part'}, {u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'it to be even more expensive for everyone else'}], u'author_id': u'18247935', u'in_reply_to': u'118390057', u'id': u'118476043', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatLogan', u'text': u'But data centres can be pretty much anywhere.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531993835000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3436229', u'in_reply_to': u'118422645', u'id': u'118474375', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'How silly of me :-( . My research company invested in a video conference room a decade ago (at a crazy price) because it was easy to see that it cut down "jet powered flights" for not all meetings, but for many many meetings.
And yes, a huge amount of research is going into making processing more efficient. Not always because engineers think about energy use, but because they think a lot about heat. Having worked with supercomputers (via net) i had a guided tour once. From an engineering point of view, a lot of the problem with computing powerhouses is how to get rid of heat on a massive scale. Thermal efficiency is a big thing on this planet. And a combustion car run on 30 percent efficiency on a good day. A coal power plant top 50 percent. Something with an electric motor and electronics often top 90 percent efficiency. 
To point at digital transfer as problem for agw is to bark up the wrong tree. 
Just a few examples. In science we have bandwidth now that allows the transfer of terabyte files from models or even remote sensing images. In 1990 when I started university, these data were still so big that it was faster to send a person across the Atlantic and bring the substantial mass of hard drives back home. Measured in gigabytes. 
So imagine that, 200 gigabyte would need a flight. Now that would cause a bit of emission. 
I remember the first global digital elevation model of the planet with a 1x1km resolution coming to university in 1993. It was fantastic - it came packed on 20 (?) CDs. By air-mail. Around 15 gbytes. Imagine if we did that still - I have no idea how many jumbo jets we would have flying with information. 
It is also worth to remember that when I finished my Cand. SC in 1997, it was high-tech that I could fill in a form for required climate data on the WWW, that then came sent to me as print outs from a server, so I could sit at the computer day in and day out and punch it into my computer (with big chance from manual mistakes). My office needs energy too, as does my computer. Heck, we used digitizing software until resent ly, to digitize graphs of data. It may not sound very scientific - but it was reality until very recent. In finishing my PhD it came back in mail in text format. Now it is just waiting to be taken down in grd formats. 
Finally, I see that USA want to make the net less neutral. That is way more scary than the internet emissions for agw. 
Information takes "power" with many meanings. Politically and physically. To the extent that låt Stephen Hawkins spent a lot of his intellect trying to resolve the paradox of black holes - pondering the problem of information being destroyed, that violate quite a number of ideas we have about "signals" (or information). To spend energy on information transfer is maybe the best we have used energy for. And it includes both jodeling and bagpipes. It takes energy both to send and receive. No different with this post. 
UK invented the train (by steam). There are better and faster and more efficient trains to move the information of my brain now. It is never zero. Because first of all I must eat and jog and sweat (in heat) and shake (in cold) to keep my brain close to 37 degrees at all times. Also to share a joke. 
Energy is never the problem, we evolved by tapping into the energy of the Sun over 4 billion years - emissions is the problem. And I fart. My computer does not.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531955939000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it was easy to see that it cut down flights', u'effect': u'my research company invested in a video conference room a decade ago at a crazy price but for many many meetings'}, {u'cause': u'not always engineers think about energy use but because they think a lot about heat', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'they think a lot about heat', u'effect': u'not always because engineers think about energy use but'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'a bit of emission'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'id': u'118462471', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anteaus', u'text': u'I would agree that there is a huge amount of planned wastage in the IT industry.
