I remember a depletion of Bus Drivers due to a massive wage increase re Ford in Dagenham and plea from the employers saying what can we offer to attract staff.Most were multi-skilled having completed apprenticeships in various trades and thereby could moonlight to supplement wages, but once longer hours were introduced such avenues of obtaining extra income were halted.
You could also threaten strike action because rent took less of the household budget and with secondary picketing being enforced it could (at times) shorten many disputes. Depends on opinion - but all I know is with overtime I cleared a £100 a week, the wife didn't need to work and with three kids, no Child Tax Credit & very low Child Benefit payments we seemed to get along fine.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528003000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a massive wage increase re ford in dagenham', u'effect': u'a depletion of bus drivers and plea from the employers saying what can we offer to attract staff'}, {u'cause': u'rent took less of the household budget and with secondary picketing being enforced', u'effect': u'you could also threaten strike action'}], u'author_id': u'3825641', u'in_reply_to': u'118710589', u'id': u'118712261', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Toiletcleaner', u'text': u'Is that the blurb for your planned autobiography?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532527695000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4132762', u'in_reply_to': u'118706126', u'id': u'118711970', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sausagerollmodel', u'text': u'And if you ignore the homeless sleeping on our streets the length and breadth of the country, or if you ignore the food banks, rising inequality or that almost a third of children are now born into poverty. Apart from healthcare it seems pretty sweet, and yet there is enough discontent to vote in Trump.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528605000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16895297', u'in_reply_to': u'118712348', u'id': u'118712830', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Fromibizatothebroads', u'text': u'What I remember well from '76 is the fact that cars were kind looking, charmingly twee in their lines and shape. And people sat on their car bonnets, leaned against them, looking out at their surroundings. As youngsters, we sat on the cars, feet on the bonnet, the windows fully wound down, usually when there were picnics. So un-Mrs Bucket-like! Mrs Bouquet rather! Sometimes even in the street you might have found a loafer or two or a couple of punk rockers leaning against your car side. Mad maybe! But that's what the soldiers did in the war movies. They sat on top of or leaned against their vehicles. Maybe it was to be within earshot of the radio. Cars now are frightening looking.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532527269000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11293785', u'id': u'118711538', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FatherLarryDuff', u'text': u'My parents have lots of photo albums which prove that the 1970s were definitely in colour.
My Dad grew up in the 40s and 50s and he assures me that everything was in black and white in those days. He even has the photos to prove it.
My Mum reckons the 60s were definitely in colour, but her photos from that time suggest she remembers wrong. I wouldn't trust any of my Mum's memories of the 60's to be honest.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528499000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14813685', u'in_reply_to': u'118692244', u'id': u'118712734', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'citizenJA', u'text': u'Yep', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532527250000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4658893', u'in_reply_to': u'118695595', u'id': u'118711521', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID5923091', u'text': u'How did you manage to sit on something like a Morris-Minor bonnet?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528417000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2759198', u'in_reply_to': u'118711538', u'id': u'118712662', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DieSubversiv', u'text': u'Didn't open until 1987.You are wrong even there - from practical memories of driving to work on the sth circular - M25 was being used in early 1986. For about a week the sth circular was empty - literally all that traffic had moved onto the M25 instead. That much reduced traffic only lasted about a month though as people realised that actually it was faster by the old road.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532527233000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15121113', u'in_reply_to': u'118709655', u'id': u'118711501', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JFBridge', u'text': u'I read AB's treatise on the 70's (When The Lights Went Out),which was an admirably neutral and objective look at the tumultuous events of the decade which started fairly benignly yet soon began to unravel in domestic and international crises such as the 1973 oil shock and the resulting stagflation,the miners strike and the three day week,the IMF loan (which actually was not needed in the end),industrial unrest and overly powerful trade unions,with the Winter of Discontent at the decades' end proving too much for the Keynesian Post-War consensus to survive as Thatcherism and free-market neoliberalism took over.
I can remember the famously long hot summer of '76 as a mere lad of 9,mostly insulated and incredulous about the precarious economic position of the country as it was then,just happy to enjoy the summer holidays with my immediate family who have now sadly all passed away.
It is arguable in this year's comparably long hot summer,that the present economic situation now is a lot,lot worse,though in a different context.The world economic crash of 10 years ago,followed by grim austerity,a welfare state and benefits under severe ideological attack and an overplus of casual,part-time and zero-hour contract work has led to the grave uncertainty of the Brexit abyss.
There ere contingency supply plans arranged for the three-day week and fuel crisis;we now have government ministers planning the same in case of a no-deal Brexit,which is not universally popular in a divided referendum vote which narrowly voted for leave,and is as much a national humiliation and disgrace now as it was over four decades ago.Neoliberalism is now straining at the edges,with Labour and not the Tories this time offering a clear alternative as Thatcher did then,with Corbyn actually offering Nordic-style social democracy on Keynesian lines as Attlee did after the war in 1945,although the far-right press and Brextremist Tory MP's inevitably will compare it to Marxism or worse,as their ideology has become so extreme as even moderate Conservatives are berated and abused viciously in the press as virtual socialist dogmatists.
Age has of course made me far more cynical,but it feels a hell of a lot unhappier and pessimistic now that 42 years ago,despite the parallel long hot summers.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528217000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the world economic crash of 10 years ago followed by grim austerity a welfare state and benefits under severe ideological attack and an overplus of casual work', u'effect': u'the grave uncertainty of the brexit'}], u'author_id': u'3060974', u'id': u'118712477', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FinMtl', u'text': u'The savior of the UK was North Sea oil and gas as it solved the balance of payments problems that limited governments options.
Also, the hollowing out of UK manufacturing was as much exposure to EEC competition for which the UK was not ready as Thatcher's policies.
Thatcher gets too much credit for improving the UK's prospects in the 80's.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532527021000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15040461', u'id': u'118711279', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Wainui01', u'text': u'I miss quarter-lights - for those who didn't want the whole window wound down', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528114000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4103130', u'in_reply_to': u'118711538', u'id': u'118712366', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'francobore', u'text': u'I have to say, living somewhere where the temperature is rarely under 30° all summer, that as per usual the UK appears ill prepared for anything, and when it does happen, the reaction is to panic and over react. Yes, most farmers have created water holes - indeed massive sprinklers are going 24/7 watering the maize fields. Cattle are still in the fields. Old people are not dying in the streets. Life goes on. Bloody hell, you have had a fortnight of not shit weather. get a grip.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532526969000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16432801', u'id': u'118711224', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Toiletcleaner', u'text': u'If you're not converting into decimal, it's as easy to count in 14s and 16s as it is in 10s.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532528099000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4132762', u'in_reply_to': u'118706320', u'id': u'118712351', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'citizenJA', u'text': u'Tory government Lets fossil fuel interests do as they like against the wishes of the people in Lancashire, for example', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532526953000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4658893', u'in_reply_to': u'118708069', u'id': u'118711217', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DieSubversiv', u'text': u'Well where were you?My first job after leaving college was to join some friends working on the M25. We were certainly materially worse off then or rather we had much less stuff but I do remember it as a happy time in contrast to the 1980s which were appalling.
I think the 1970s has been misjudged. It was a very different country then and needed to change in many ways but I don't think what came next was so marvelous. For a lot of people this meant that their mortgages were virtually paid down without them having to do anything.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532526321000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14468631', u'in_reply_to': u'118708591', u'id': u'118710589', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Wainui01', u'text': u'If you had a band called Digital Detox in the 70's people wouldn't have known what it meant - even Bowie's Space Oddity made no reference to digital circuitry', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532526302000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4103130', u'in_reply_to': u'118708633', u'id': u'118710568', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID5923091', u'text': u'Yes, I think the endless exposure to what's going on in the world is wearying. Look at Tommy Tiernan "Too much information" on YouTube. We don't use "extreme" any more. Nor "Bizarre." "Everything is bizarre" quipped a friend. Or nothing is, depending on your view point. Maybe we could set up a "Survivors of '76" Facebook group. Lots of other nostalgia groups there. Reading other people's comments, it was a special time for Brits. Imagine what it was like for me, my first year in the U.K. - away from all the political/religious b.s. that personified Ireland. I went a bit mad. Of course if I had my time again I'd go outright crazy. So to complete my nostalgia trip, I'll put a selection of my favourite Motown records on my (1974) Pioneer Pl12D turntable while I flick through a "Bike" magazine of that era. English-Irishman. Not recognised as an aberration - yet.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532526115000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2759198', u'in_reply_to': u'118708633', u'id': u'118710381', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MungoBeerBelly', u'text': u'Why stop at 1976, why not 1076 - lords, serfs, slaves, no mobile phones, barber-surgeons, leprosy, the plague, torture. in order to prevent massive inflation as the natural consequence of printing a load of pocket money you have to have huge tax rates to rake it all back in again.
BQEND
The limitation is always the availability of real resources, not fiat money. The Weimar hyperinflation was the result of a catastrophic collapse in productive capacity due to the war and a vast foreign currency debt obligation also due to war reparations. There was little availability of real goods & services to purchase with the newly created Mark currency and so hyperinflation followed. (Ditto for Zimbabwe).
Neither of these factors apply to a developed economy in peace time (e.g. Britain) which is a monopoly fiat currency issuer and so has no need to rack up foreign currency debt obligations. These nations are also economic entities with massive productive capacity and more capacity lying idle (e.g labour) which can be easily activated if the necessary money was made available. The mainstream narrative uses Weimar, Zimbabwe, Venezuela etc. as the economic equivalent of the bogeyman used to scare bold children up to bed.
There is no simple cause and effect relationship between monetary expansion and inflation or Fx depreciation. Damaging levels of inflation will only occur when there is chronic excess demand relative to the real capacity of the economy to produce output or import to meet that demand. This is rarely a concern in a modern economy which produces or can import an excess of virtually all essential goods & services relative to demand. In other words there is no inflation risk in the creation of new money once there is sufficient real wealth of goods and services and productive capacity to absorb the demand that the additional money will stimulate as clearly borne out in the data: “Based on our examination of countries that together constitute 91 percent of world GDP, we suggest that high inflation has infrequently followed rapid money supply growth, and in contrast to this, high inflation has occurred often when it has not been preceded by rapid money supply growth”
http://evonomics.com/moneysupply/
In fact most of the monetary expansion is now the result of commercial bank lending rather than via currency issuing governments. While the commercial banks have no role in controlling inflation or Fx rates. Each new loan creates new money in the form of a bank deposit. Since the 1980s the global money supply across all the major currencies has increased almost exponentially as the deregulated commercial banks massively increased their loan books and expanded the money supply (The money is extinguished as the loans are repaid but at a much slower pace). And yet there has been no hyperinflation that the monetarists continually hyperventilate about.
http://positivemoney.org/how-money-works/how-much-money-have-banks-created/
You see the capitalist elite have no issue with vast levels of money creation once its purpose is to enrich the financial sector through commercial bank lending to fuel property bubbles or via QE for example or to protect the 1% in the colossal bailout of the delinquent banking sector in 2008 or even to engage in illegal wars in Iraq. But money creation to serve the interests of the majority such as properly funding the NHS, social housing, transport systems or cladding tall buildings in fireproof panels is considered to be economic heresy.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532525488000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'war reparations', u'effect': u'the weimar hyperinflation was the result of a catastrophic collapse in productive capacity due to the war and a vast foreign currency debt obligation also'}, {u'cause': u'the war and a vast foreign currency debt obligation', u'effect': u'a catastrophic collapse in productive capacity'}], u'author_id': u'17748976', u'in_reply_to': u'118708589', u'id': u'118709735', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stu365', u'text': u'So you're saying that in the 70s tattoos weren't fashionable, food was more scarce, and mobile phones for the mass consumer hadn't been invented yet?

description: The sense of ease in Britain over those months was not a total delusion. Yet the year brought huge political upheaval, says Guardian feature writer and author Andy Beckett
og_fields.og:description: The sense of ease in Britain over those months was not a total delusion. Yet the year brought huge political upheaval, says Guardian feature writer and author Andy Beckett
og_fields.og:title: It feels like 1976. And that long, hot summer didn’t end well | Andy Beckett
text:
Just like this year’s, the heatwave in 1976 arrived as Britain seemed to be approaching an economic and political abyss. During the spring and early summer, as the sun began to hammer down and the usual rain failed to fall, and the reservoirs began to shrink, the pound was lurching downwards on the markets. For almost three years, under Tory and Labour governments, the economy had been shrivelling alarmingly. Just as since the Brexit vote, a conviction had been building like a thundercloud among financial traders and business leaders, economists and commentators, in Britain and beyond, that the country was about to slip to a lower, less elite level, and stay there. “Goodbye, Great Britain,” said a much-read editorial in the Wall Street Journal in 1975, “it was nice knowing you.”
If you remember the British summer of 1976 we'd like to hear from you. What do you remember? How does it compare to this year? 
You can share your photos and memories by filling in this encrypted form. One of our journalists may be in touch and we will consider some of your responses in our reporting. You can read terms of service here.
To some pessimists about Britain’s prospects, the drought the following summer, which brought forest fires, crop failures, hosepipe bans enforced by policemen and vigilantes, and standpipes on street corners instead of mains water, was a further sign of crisis. In 1976, with impeccable timing, the American writer Paul Theroux published The Family Arsenal, a bleakly satirical novel about terrorists on the loose in a sweaty, rundown mid-70s London, its “decay pushing towards ruin”. Some sort of apocalypse, predicted one of the characters, was “certainly coming”.
But the Labour chancellor, Denis Healey, was not one of the worriers. In the summer of 1976, after several exhausting months trying to defend his economic policies and the value of the pound, he went on holiday for most of August. He left sticky London behind and drove unhurriedly through England and Wales and up to north-west Scotland. “Not a drop of rain,” he wrote in his memoirs, “even in the Highlands.” In the hidden away lochside town of Ullapool, Healey checked into a hotel on the quayside and began to relax.
That night, he was repeatedly woken by phone calls from Whitehall. In the US currency markets, the pound was collapsing again. The hotel had only one phone, so the chancellor stood in a hallway with a coat over his pyjamas, authorising the Bank of England to spend “up to $150m” (about £750m now) to buy sterling. The intervention worked: the pound stopped falling. Healey went back to bed, and then continued with his holiday.
Hot weather does contradictory things to British politics. In parliament, with its stuffy rooms and sweaty dress codes, it traditionally sparks revolts, plots, panics and flashes of temper – a sense that things are coming to a head – as it has this summer. Yet away from Westminster, a heatwave can make politicians, and even more so voters, worry less than usual about the state of the nation. In an overcast country, sunshine often means contentment and escapism – and procrastination. During July and August 1976, despite the state of the economy and a widespread disillusionment with centre-left politics (which had been deepening since the late 60s), the Labour government pulled level with the Conservatives in the polls. Healey was generally seen as a tough, capable chancellor. The prime minister, Jim Callaghan, had an avuncular, calming manner that seemed appropriate to the summer lull. Voters called him Sunny Jim.
Theresa May has none of Callaghan’s sly charm. But her situation this summer is similar in some ways. As in 1976, a divided government in a weak parliamentary position, wedded to increasingly contested ideas – for Callaghan, postwar social democracy, for May, austerity and the free market – has somehow made it to the welcome shade of the recess, despite many predictions to the contrary. The main opposition party remains ominously strong, but it has an intensely divisive leader whom many voters see as odd and extremist: in this sense, Margaret Thatcher was the Jeremy Corbyn of the mid-70s.
And, just as Callaghan did, May has managed to put off the most difficult political question of her government until the autumn. In 1976, this was whether Britain could afford to continue with its postwar levels of state spending; now it is how to do Brexit. Yet during what might be a once-in-a-generation summer – as the sun keeps shining, day after day, and the parks are full of impromptu skivers, the pubs are full of workers having cheeky afternoon lagers, and even supposedly earnest protest marches feel more like carnivals – such national dilemmas can feel very distant.
In the summer of 1976, the sense of ease was not a total delusion. Twenty-eight years later, the respected New Economics Foundation created a measure for overall economic, social and environmental wellbeing, and concluded that 1976 was the best year in modern British history.
In late August the heatwave finally disintegrated in a mess of thunderstorms. A soaking, grey autumn followed
For those invested in the idea that the 70s were a nadir for Britain – pro-Thatcher historians, and hipper archivists of the punk rebellion against the mid-70s status quo – the summer of 1976 has always been an awkward piece of counter-evidence. Yet as Jon Savage pointed out in his 1991 book England’s Dreaming, still the best, most nuanced study of punk and its political and social context, the heatwave actually helped the movement. After dark, the rare warmth gave the first British punks a sense of possibility, and a freedom, as they roamed between squats and nightclubs. In a normal British summer, it would have been hard to stay out all night in punk outfits full of holes.
The summer of 2018 feels less carefree. We know more about climate change and skin cancer now. This week, forecast to be the hottest of the season, the Met Office is advising people to stay out of the sun. And the world beyond Britain feels more genuinely apocalyptic, and harder to ignore. We face Trump and a Europe increasingly controlled by far-right populists; in the summer of 1976, the continent was dominated by centrists, and the insurgent shaking up US politics was a mild, almost meek Democrat, Jimmy Carter. Even the cold war seemed to be abating, thanks to the disarmament treaties and subtle diplomacy of detente.
But we shouldn’t idealise the summer of 1976 too much. Away from its unexpected pleasures, pressures were still building in Britain. In August the guitarist Eric Clapton near the peak of his fame, used a concert in Birmingham to make a speech defending the anti-immigrant prejudices of Enoch Powell. At the end of the month, the Notting Hill carnival in London turned into a battle between the police and black youths, a prefiguring of the many riots in the decade to come.
Also in late August the heatwave finally disintegrated in a mess of thunderstorms. A soaking, grey autumn followed. The pound resumed its decline, the government’s finances deteriorated further, Whitehall panicked – or, some say, exploited the situation – and the government ended up drastically cutting its spending, and accepting a loan from the IMF. The reputations of Healey and Callaghan, their government, and postwar social democracy, never quite recovered.
Once the summer interlude of 1976 was over, Britain changed very fast – and in many ways not for the good. Perhaps that’s something for Theresa May, and the rest of us, to ponder while we enjoy the sun.
• Andy Beckett is a feature writer for the Guardian
... The Guardian is here to help guide you through whatever lies ahead. More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

So, for years I thought I had climate change figured out. I had read the books and articles, and watched the documentaries and videos.
However, I still had my reservations
1) Historically, the bulk of warming seems to have been driven by methane. So why are we so concerned about CO2? 
2) In the past, we have had up to 4000ppm carbon dioxide. So why should we care if it goes up another 280ppm, or even triples?
Basically, after reading James Hansens book 'Storms of our Grandchildren', I was able to put the pieces together. 
Carbon dioxide is the trigger for methane releases, which really cause the most damage. Methane is released from thawing permafrost, and ice within the ocean.
The reason we had higher levels of CO2 in the past is that the sun will die in 7.6 billion years. Many of the extinction events in Earths history happened 100s if not thousands of millions of years ago. This means that the sun was about 1-2% dimmer. The cumulative effect of 1-2% of suns energy on the planet is profound.
The planet has been very, very good at maintaining an atmospheric balance of elements such that temperatures rarely reach life-threatening extremes. This is because things have happened over geological timescales in the past, and life has found a way to fill in the gaps and if not correct itself, to bring the planet back from one extreme or another.
Unfortunately, things are happening much faster now.

i really don't believe a court has the power to force a government to change its policies.
BQEND there has already been a successful case in the Netherlands:

BQSTART
The 2015 Urgenda Climate Case against the Dutch Government was the first in the world in which citizens held their government accountable for contributing to dangerous climate change. On 24 June 2015, the District Court of The Hague ruled the government must cut its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 25% by the end of 2020 (compared to 1990 levels). The ruling required the government to immediately take more effective action on climate change. 
The case, which was brought on behalf of 886 Dutch citizens, made climate change a major political and social issue in the Netherlands and transformed domestic climate change policy. It inspired climate change cases in Belgium, New Zealand, Ireland, the UK, Switzerland and the US.
BQEND
Climate Case - Urgenda
The government appealed the court's decision in May of this year and the case will be decided on 9th October - it's by no means a foregone conclusion the Netherlands govt. will win the appeal. Meanwhile a great raise in public awareness and discussion of the issue. 
The reason that children - or teens - are doing this is because it's their future most at risk. They may certainly be well informed at this age - sometimes a lot more than many of the adult population.

BQSTART
THE OSLO PRINCIPLES 
On 30 March 2015 the Oslo Principles on Global Climate Change Obligations were launched, formulated by an international group of eminent jurists, including High Court judges, law professors and advocates from countries such as Brazil, China, India, the US and the Netherlands. The Oslo principles hold that regardless of the existence of international agreements, governments already have a legal obligation to avert the harmful effects of climate change, based on existing international human rights law, environmental law and tort law. . . . . . According to Spier, ‘Courts can force countries to adopt effective climate policies. Court cases are perhaps the only way to break through the political apathy about climate change.

Methane is a very powerful greenhouse gas so, although burning methane produces less CO2 than burning coal,any leakage of methane from the fracking sites will quickly cancel out any benefits. It also means that gas fired power stations will remain in operation for far longer.
We should instead be increasing the rate we deploy wind farms, solar generation and HVDC interconnector links to other countries. We have so much potential for renewable energy generation we could once again become a net exporter of energy if we so choose.

To consider the same issue another way, bear in mind that 10% of the world's population output 50% of all greenhouse gases, while 50% are responsible for 95% of all emissions. The other half of the world's population emit only 5% of all GHGs, so blaming population growth for exascerbating climate change is both ill-informed, and very misleading.

description: Editorial: Adapting to hotter temperatures is sensible – but ignoring their causes is dangerous
og_fields.og:description: Editorial: Adapting to hotter temperatures is sensible – but ignoring their causes is dangerous
og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on the heatwave: our climate is endangered | Editorial
text:
The NHS is experiencing a “summer crisis”, with increased emergency admissions and uncomfortable conditions in buildings not equipped for the heat, while the Met Office has warned that the UK temperature record of 38.5C could be broken on Friday. Authorities in Greece are dealing with the aftermath of devastating wildfires that killed at least 85 people, while efforts to control blazes in Sweden and in California continue. In Japan, 23,000 people have been taken to hospital in the past week and the weather described by officials as a “disaster”. In Algeria, a new African record has been set of 51.3C.
Weather systems are highly complex and scientists are cautious about assigning specific causes to one-off events. But experts are already pointing to global warming as a driver for the current heatwave, with a study based on computer models and temperature data due to be published by scientists at Oxford University on Friday. Meanwhile, a new report from the environmental audit committee points to the likelihood of more frequent heatwaves in future, and the UK government’s failure to prepare adequately for them.
There’s nothing wrong with enjoying the heatwave, as many people are. Such a long spell of warm weather is extraordinary and, for sun lovers, a treat. No doubt many are hoping it doesn’t break before they take their holidays. But whether or not any more records are broken, or wildfires ignited in the coming weeks, the claim that rising temperatures have nothing to do with the global state of extreme weather must not go unchallenged.
When the former US environment secretary Scott Pruitt was asked about climate change following Hurricane Harvey last year, he said that it was not the right time to talk about it. The opposite case is that the aftermath of an extreme event, when the atmospheric conditions have become the news, rather than the backdrop to the news, can be a “teachable moment”, when different kinds of conversations become possible.
One of those conversations is the one about adaptation. Since some effects of climate change are now inevitable, we must deal with them. As this week’s committee report says, building regulations must be altered to ensure heat resilience, and new measures must be brought in to improve drainage and water efficiency.
The public information campaign that the committee calls for is even more urgent. The 2008 Climate Change Act commits the UK government to reducing emissions by 80% of their 1990 levels by 2050. The latest British Social Attitudes survey showed that more than 90% of British people accept that climate change is happening. But only around a quarter describe themselves as very worried about this. Politicians, along with journalists, scientists and others, have a responsibility to make sure that people know what to expect and can make informed decisions – for example, about how to heat and insulate their own homes.
Treating the symptoms of climate change makes no sense if the causes are not tackled at the same time. British laws – as well as the Paris agreement – commit the UK government to doing this, meaning decarbonisation of the electricity supply, heating and transport. These measures have cross-party support, but commitment by politicians is inconsistent. Just a few weeks ago, parliament approved a new runway at Heathrow, a decision that now faces a legal challenge. This week, the government gave approval for fracking in Lancashire, enraging all those who fear that this is proof – combined with slashed solar subsidies, the de facto ban on new onshore wind farms, and the rejection of the Swansea bay tidal scheme – that the government is unenthusiastic about renewables.
Enjoy the sun if you can. We only live once and in countries with temperate climates such as the UK not all of the effects of climate change are necessarily harmful. Domestic tourism could even benefit. But don’t lose sight of the suffering caused by higher temperatures. In all our hands rests the future of life on earth.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for our species and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

article_tags: [Climate change, Natural disasters and extreme weather, UK weather, Environment, World news, UK news]
description: Exclusive: Prof Michael Mann declares the impacts of global warming are now ‘playing out in real-time’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Exclusive: Prof Michael Mann declares the impacts of global warming are now ‘playing out in real-time’
og_fields.og:title: Extreme global weather is 'the face of climate change' says leading scientist
text:
The extreme heatwaves and wildfires wreaking havoc around the globe are “the face of climate change,” one of the world’s leading climate scientists has declared, with the impacts of global warming now “playing out in real time.”
Climate change has long been predicted to increase extreme weather incidents, and scientists are now confident these predictions are coming true. Scientists say the global warming has contributed to the scorching temperatures that have baked the UK and northern Europe for weeks.
The hot spell was made more than twice as likely by climate change, a new analysis found, demonstrating an “unambiguous” link. 
Extreme weather has struck across Europe, from the Arctic Circle to Greece, and across the world, from North America to Japan. “This is the face of climate change,” said Prof Michael Mann, at Penn State University, and one the world’s most eminent climate scientists. “We literally would not have seen these extremes in the absence of climate change.”
“The impacts of climate change are no longer subtle,” he told the Guardian. “We are seeing them play out in real time and what is happening this summer is a perfect example of that.”
“We are seeing our predictions come true,” he said. “As a scientist that is reassuring, but as a citizen of planet Earth, it is very distressing to see that as it means we have not taken the necessary action.”
The rapid scientific assessment of the northern European heatwave was done by Geert Jan van Oldenborgh, at the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute and also colleagues in the World Weather Attribution (WWA) consortium. “We can see the fingerprints of climate change on local extremes,” he said.
The current heatwave has been caused by an extraordinary stalling of the jet stream wind, which usually funnels cool Atlantic weather over the continent. This has left hot, dry air in place for two months – far longer than usual. The stalling of the northern hemisphere jet stream is being increasingly firmly linked to global warming, in particular to the rapid heating of the Arctic and resulting loss of sea ice.
Prof Mann said that asking if climate change “causes” specific events is the wrong question: “The relevant question is: ‘Is climate change impacting these events and making them more extreme?’, and we can say with great confidence that it is.”
Mann points out that the link between smoking tobacco and lung cancer is a statistical one, which does not prove every cancer was caused by smoking, but epidemiologists know that smoking greatly increases the risk. “That is enough to say that, for all practical purposes, there is a causal connection between smoking cigarettes and lung cancer and it is the same with climate change,” Mann said.
Other senior scientists agree the link is clear. Serious climate change is “unfolding before our eyes”, said Prof Rowan Sutton, at the University of Reading. “No one should be in the slightest surprised that we are seeing very serious heatwaves and associated impacts in many parts of the world.”
It is not too late to make the significant cuts needed in greenhouse gas emissions, said Mann, because the impacts progressively worsen as global warming increases. 
“It is not going off a cliff, it is like walking out into a minefield,” he said. “So the argument it is too late to do something would be like saying: ‘I’m just going to keep walking’. That would be absurd – you reverse course and get off that minefield as quick as you can. It is really a question of how bad it is going to get.”
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for humanity and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

[{u'author': u'uncommodified', u'text': u'I make a point of bringing up climate change whenever I talk to an affluent middle class person. They need to be told NO, you CAN'T retire on a fat fossil fuelled pension, you CAN'T invest in things that wreck the planet, you CAN'T do the school run in a bloated 4x4, you CAN'T have all the Made In China gadgets, you CAN'T keep flying around on weekend city breaks or to "find yourself" backpacking in southeast Asia. The environment is more important.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532862846000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18309811', u'in_reply_to': u'118862877', u'id': u'118863109', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'317east', u'text': u'People are very selfish and preserving the environment interferes with their money grubbing and cat fighting.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532862843000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11751798', u'in_reply_to': u'118857719', u'id': u'118863106', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'christophertill', u'text': u'And another thing. Also, unlike Hinkley, it was not all going to be money handed over to the French and Chinese so keeping jobs and money in the UK, especially in a region that is desperate for investment.This would have been a World's first and although turbines might not be new, the engineering and array of turbines in this configuration with a lagoon is most definitely a new technology, one that Britain could indeed have exported, not just in terms of build but moreover in training and servicing which I believe now is the most profitable area of engineering these days.Also, there's no joined up thinking here. This would have also been a great leisure and tourist pull for the area. Messed up isn’t it?', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532862169000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4266804', u'id': u'118862544', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jim987', u'text': u'Climate Change is emblematic of the perilous state of Western Democracy. We have an existential crisis in our face as we speak, yet the political classes and a good solid chunk of the voters ignore it as if it wasn't there. This Country is completely beholden to America and the Right Wing political movement it spawned. Politicians and political hacks alike are completely supine to the Americans and nothing, not even the collapse of whole ecosystems can be allowed to interrupt the nauseating arse licking. As a consequence we see shocking failures (outside Climate Change) and people tend to pussyfoot around lest a Tory or even, God forbid, an American be slightly offended by a bit of telling truth to power.
The science has been researched to destruction. The consensus is, at least twenty years, yet the deniers are still out in force, regurgitating the same lamentable shite they did thirty years ago. Why? Why are STILL having to plough right this nonsense when the seas boiling, forest fires raging in the artic?
We can complain about this for the next twenty years, or we can tackle the people responsible. The gloves need to come off and these people need to be taken to task.
The science has been drilled down for a hundred and fifty years to the point where we are today. If we are being honest here, the science underpinning the Greenhouse effect is not under any serious dispute, certainly not to the extent the Right Wing media would have us believe. 
The Right Wing here and in America have a vested interest in persisting with this myth that the science is flawed or the scientists are falsifying the laws of physics for gain. The lies are ludicrous and yet no one is really seriously question these morons. 
These Right Wing morons are wrong on this subject and have been for the last thirty years. As the implications for what was needed to alleviate Global Warming became clear they picked the wrong side of the debate then, and they are wrong now. The problem is that the answer was on the page. The science was open to scrutiny, the scientists were telling you he answer, the evidence was mounting up and yet they still managed to get it wrong. Why? How on Earth could they get it wrong on a non political issue? How?
Could it be that these people are ideological zealots? Is it possible that these people are too stupid to think rationally? They cannot get the right answer when the right answer is right in front of them, blinded by ideology how can they get genuinely difficult question correct?', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532862162000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12673774', u'id': u'118862536', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Guimard', u'text': u'Only thing his ever made that has actual made money , how is that for irony .', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532862086000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10011106', u'in_reply_to': u'118861884', u'id': u'118862475', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'funnybum07', u'text': u'What advances would they be.I remember watching g tomorrow's world in the seventies .They said we would be living on the moon now. A more cynical view is that politicians only want to focus on decisions that have a quick payback for them, preferably within their own term of office, or within a 5 year time frame.
Global warming does not fit with this short termi view, raising the very serious question about whether democratic structures can really deliver with the urgency we need?
Michael Gove should also accept that there is little point to Brexit when it is clear that the climate does not respect borders, and that it is not a problem that will be solved by nation states in isolation. A bit like insisting on class segregation on the Titanic half an hour before we hit the iceberg.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861989000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3130397', u'id': u'118862379', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Apostrophe Z', u'text': u'Thanks for keeping this issue on the public's radar. With rain and winds rolling in, some might be tempted to forget how the early summer of 2018 was a bit of a time machine set to the near future. The exact date may remain unknown at this point, but we can certainly see this as a direction of travel.
It's a real shame because the basic physics of CO2 as a greenhouse were twice and independently confirmed in the late 19th C and reconfirmed twice again in the early to mid 1900s. It's not like we haven't been warned. It was in 1986 that Hansen gave his now famous address to Congress and spoke of 99.9% confidence that the global climate was changing, that it was largely due to CO2, with other GHG, and almost entirely due to human activity. To this we can qualify this as 'human economic activity'.
This is clearly stated in the recent permissions granted for fracking in Lancs. Not only does it promote the use of gas (a fossil fuel), it also uses up humungous volumes of water, discharges chemical toxins into the local area, and is a practice that has been associated with earthquakes.
There are as many (potential) solutions as there are people, especially those living in the industrialised world and generate the largest collective footprint of the global population. Many of these will need to be driven by leaders (so that wouldn't include the current administration in either the UK nor the US), and the media have a role to play too. Perhaps even challenging politicians lack of action; perhaps challenging corporate practices that makes it cheaper to pay the fine than it is to limit the practice even though the impacts on the local and wider areas may last for decades with unknown human suffering. Perhaps, using 'nudge theory', the barriers to full-scale roll out of an integrated strategy can be removed, and to invest in a national green engineering and infrastructure project ... making the UK be newsworthy for reasons about which we can be proud, rather than embarrassed on the world stage.
Will it happen? I sure hope so, but I think that humans are not well attuned to perceiving slow moving (temporal distance) and supra-scale changes, and therefore are not likely to respond meaningfully to AGW and CC until it is right on our doorstep - even while it is happening elsewhere, these changes are still distant from our perspective, because we are not used to thinking in terms of systems, scales and speeds. For many politicians, corporate leaders, and the popular media (who are the levers of potential change at the scale required), AGW and CC are still spoken about in terms of "belief", as if there is something that we are having faith, that is a matter of belief rather than a physical experiment that demonstrates the same outcome reliably over and again: CO2 is a greenhouse gas of significant influence.
Nor is it a belief insofar as it is actually happening? How did people think CC was going to happen? It will, and already has begun to change the weather patterns towards what has been anticipated in various scenarios modelled by a host of scientists, reported in academic and policy papers since the early 1990s, at least. Of course, the climate has always changed. In itself, that's not the point. What is the crux of the concern is the speed or rate of change. In human lifespan terms, it may not seem immediate, or critical, but in planetary times, this is happening fast!
We are so brilliant a species in some ways, and can see so far with such clarity of vision and imagination. In others, we still grope about blindly for our fundamental behaviours still seem driven by an ancient evolutionary pattern for competition and aggression and short-termist gain (hedonism). Ironically, is it not our very brilliance and clear vision that have both mitigated our blindness while amplifying its effects?', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861972000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the basic physics of co2 as a greenhouse were', u'effect': u"it 's a real shame twice and independently confirmed in the late 19th c and reconfirmed twice again in the early to mid 1900s"}, {u'cause': u'human activity', u'effect': u'with other ghg and'}, {u'cause': u'co2', u'effect': u'that it was with other ghg'}, {u'cause': u'we are not used to thinking in terms of systems', u'effect': u'even while it is happening elsewhere these changes are still distant from our perspective'}], u'author_id': u'100579422', u'id': u'118862362', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheDoctorOfLetters', u'text': u'Agreed. By the time we go into full on WW2 level panic mode mitigation it will be far too late and I think there is a real possibility of billions of deaths from simultaneous crop failures around the world.We are already seeing a taste of it right now.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861958000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17443130', u'in_reply_to': u'118854905', u'id': u'118862346', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Artistview', u'text': u'Climate change is expected to be back next weekend, so don't put those sun loungers away just yet.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861956000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15202233', u'id': u'118862345', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Philw49', u'text': u'He’s just pointing out blatant hypocrisy!', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861938000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12608734', u'in_reply_to': u'118862153', u'id': u'118862327', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Neil__McFarlane', u'text': u'Change would come tomorrow if politicians feared the people at the next election. They may be wrong, but they are currently occupying the same position as Galileo-a minority viewpoint opposed by the overwhelming majority of experts of their day:
Khabibullo Abdusamatov, astrophysicist at Pulkovo Observatory of the Russian Academy of Sciences.Sallie Baliunas, retired astrophysicist, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics.Timothy Ball, historical climatologist, and retired professor of geography at the University of Winnipeg.Ian Clark, hydrogeologist, professor, Department of Earth Sciences, University of Ottawa.Vincent Courtillot, geophysicist, member of the French Academy of Sciences.Doug Edmeades, PhD., soil scientist, officer of the New Zealand Order of Merit.David Douglass, solid-state physicist, professor, Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Rochester.Don Easterbrook, emeritus professor of geology, Western Washington University.William Happer, physicist specializing in optics and spectroscopy; emeritus professor, Princeton University.Ole Humlum, professor of geology at the University of Oslo.Wibjörn Karlén, professor emeritus of geography and geology at the University of Stockholm.William Kininmonth, meteorologist, former Australian delegate to World Meteorological Organization Commission for Climatology.David Legates, associate professor of geography and director of the Center for Climatic Research, University of Delaware.Anthony Lupo, professor of atmospheric science at the University of Missouri.Tad Murty, oceanographer; adjunct professor, Departments of Civil Engineering and Earth Sciences, University of Ottawa.Tim Patterson, paleoclimatologist and professor of geology at Carleton University in Canada.Ian Plimer, professor emeritus of mining geology, the University of Adelaide.Arthur B. Robinson,biochemist and former faculty member at the University of California, San Diego.Murry Salby, atmospheric scientist, former professor at Macquarie University and University of Colorado.Nicola Scafetta, research scientist in the physics department at Duke University.Tom Segalstad, geologist; associate professor at University of Oslo.Nir Shaviv, professor of physics focusing on astrophysics and climate science at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.Fred Singer, professor emeritus of environmental sciences at the University of Virginia.Willie Soon, astrophysicist, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics.Roy Spencer, meteorologist; principal research scientist, University of Alabama in Huntsville.Henrik Svensmark, physicist, Danish National Space Center.George H. Taylor, retired director of the Oregon Climate Service at Oregon State University.Jan Veizer, environmental geochemist, professor emeritus from University of Ottawa.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861476000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'natural processes rather than human interference', u'effect': u'climate change'}], u'author_id': u'1304161', u'in_reply_to': u'118856577', u'id': u'118861979', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mickeyrat', u'text': u'A car can be replaced with a train which would greatly reduce the need for cars for a start. People always put off difficult things until it becomes imperative to deal with. I've even been asked how come are we feeling the effects now, when the scientists said it would happen in 2050 or 2100.We also presume that politicians are paid to think long term, and yet history shows that they don't.The only long term planners are big industry. And they realised that it wan't in their interest to act on the information they held except to reap as much benefit as possible before disaster strikes.So now that we know what's going on, now that we've realised that we're all going to have to deal with this, we must force our politicians to act. And one of those actions will have to be curbing the industrial cause.But we also need to think seriously about our own actions, our own lifestyles.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861335000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13446582', u'id': u'118861848', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Neil__McFarlane', u'text': u'"There is a school of thought that contends that politics is fundamentally incapable of addressing this challenge. During your countless rendezvous with MPs in Westminster wine bars and restaurants, how many times have you pressed them about this, the most important issue by a country mile humanity and the world currently faces? I'm going to guess zero.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861291000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18529909', u'id': u'118861822', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'trojunhorse99', u'text': u'I disagree, there is one, unfortunately they are terrified of him holding big corporations to account. Which party is the guardian tirelessly working to undermine?', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532861001000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2918970', u'id': u'118861597', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ThanksNeolibZombies', u'text': u'Excellent article.
BQSTART
Stronger action will require politicians ready to drive global warming up the agenda, lead public opinion and take bold decisions, many of which will be tough and some of which will not be popular with everyone. This politicians will do only if they genuinely care about climate change or are made to care because a critical mass of their voters tell them that they want something done.

That is what we need, a critical mass of voters demanding the massive, rapid cuts in CO2 emissions that are necessary to make the future viable. Without that, politicians will never act to cut the profits of the sociopathic fossil industry that funds election campaigns.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860967000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a critical mass of their voters tell them that they want something done', u'effect': u'are made to care'}], u'author_id': u'14984190', u'id': u'118861570', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Linda Roberts', u'text': u'The tide doesn't stop turning in winter. We could close bedroom doors and turn down radiators in rooms we are not using. We could stop throwing out useable clothes because they're not the latest fashion. Only democratic, green, socialism can give us a chance against climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860683000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18351308', u'id': u'118861334', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'Please, we have anti science AGW denial- don't counter it with anti science.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860621000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'118860244', u'id': u'118861284', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LocknessMunster', u'text': u'Firstly, it wasn't Galileo's 'opinion' it was the empirical evidence that anyone with a telescope could see for themselves.Secondly, Galileo was the expert and the Church were the denial industry.Thirdly, you are clearly an ignorant fool.', u'recommendation_count': u'24', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860613000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17443130', u'in_reply_to': u'118854941', u'id': u'118861277', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stevelnku', u'text': u'Economic Sustainability and Environmental Sustainability should be the only criteria for political decisions. 
Everything else is white noise and cognitive biases or lobbyists squewing decisions.
What countermeasures are you doing to get your property to zero, and then negative carbon? The big energy companies are trying to keep your custom and make it difficult for you to go off grid, and or sell surplus to the grid. 
Micro wind, photovoltaic, or communal geothermal are all potentially feasible to many areas. Electrical storage batteries will be normal in most houses olin a few decades. Cheaper in the long rub to take action now.
Malthusian Population Theory shows a crash is likely, private water and food security is critical. Recycling grey water, and setting up 24 hour UV growing rooms might become essential.
I am an optimistic person, but I am not optimistic that a technocentric solution to global warming and climate change will come soon. The warnings in the Stern Report on Climate Change are biblical in scale. This should concern our actions every day.
Civil unrest and resource wars are inevitable.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860533000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100369699', u'id': u'118861218', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Linda Roberts', u'text': u'A right-wing but environmentally sound Party is a contradiction in terms.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860490000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17383336', u'in_reply_to': u'118859077', u'id': u'118861179', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tomatoshi', u'text': u'Not enough action has been taken against the global scam known as cryptocurrencies and the massive energy consumption, global warming and e-waste it has been contributing to. Nowhere near as raving mad!)', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860357000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17383336', u'in_reply_to': u'118857581', u'id': u'118861052', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Delius', u'text': u'I’m not sure under-informed, over-opinionated columnists are part of the solution, even assuming a solution exists.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860352000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2611744', u'id': u'118861041', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'yeshiuk', u'text': u'Andrew, I popped round to Kings Place in the recent heat to work in the lobby, as it was suitably cool, my flat was too hot.Anyway, thanks for the article - journalists (print and broadcast) being more incisive in challenging interviewees (on climate, on Brexit) will also help get us away from the current slide into ignorance.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860348000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4136041', u'id': u'118861039', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TwinkletheCat', u'text': u'Evolution is messy, embrace it', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860321000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14512144', u'in_reply_to': u'118860102', u'id': u'118861019', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hundredhander', u'text': u'Just when we need international cooperation, working together, strong and binding international treaties, the most powerful leaders putting climate change (and other environmental issue) at the top of the agenda and making policy based on the most robust scientific evidence. 
Instead, we have fragmentation, manipulation, lobbying, political corruption, greed, lousy populism and power in the hands of ever fewer people.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860285000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4649110', u'id': u'118860993', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'morelightlessheat', u'text': u'The Tories have a very close relationship with the country’s biggest housing developers.
Labour wanted all new houses from 2016 to be carbon neutral but the lobbyists soon got to work on Cameron and Osborne and love of money for the developers and love of power by the politicians soon kicked that onto the long grass.
We have the knowledge and means to make every house carbon neutral but £100 million bonuses for the bosses of big developers trump that every time.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860275000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2939127', u'id': u'118860988', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'algae64', u'text': u'Large scale tidal power projects will eventually happen in the UK, but I don't think the Swansea scheme was the way to go. Of course that doesn't excuse Heathrow, or the failure to support other renewable energy sources. However surprisingly with Gove at DEFRA, maybe we finally have someone clever and ambitious enough in charge, to actually make some genuine progress. Won't be holding my breath though.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860044000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4604415', u'id': u'118860805', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID7490380', u'text': u'The voters have chosen Ukip instead as the pressure party, they don't give a shit about the future. Global Warming is increasingly looking like the planets immune system kicking in to rid itself of greedy and ignorant parasites.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532860030000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4416903', u'id': u'118860792', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pantokrator', u'text': u'Still awaiting news on planet B from our great leaders.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859984000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1978779', u'id': u'118860749', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Linda Roberts', u'text': u'If nobody has children, the human race is doomed whatever happens to the climate! Some people have to have children to keep the human world going for those who don't. You also need to look at which children are supposedly causing the problem. A child in the US or the UK probably consumes several times more of the earth's resources than a child from a less "developed" nation. Excessive consumption- of all resources - and waste resulting from this, are the real problems.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859984000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'children', u'effect': u'the problem'}], u'author_id': u'17383336', u'in_reply_to': u'118851712', u'id': u'118860748', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swimbouy', u'text': u'BQSTART
It implies that if we had an effect one way, then it must be possible for us to have the reverse effect. Hence we can manipulate everything the way we want it. Dream on.
BQEND
Of course it doesn’t. To reverse the effects of global warming requires negative emissions technologies, of which BECCS is the only feasible technology which requires vast amounts of land to be dedicated to growing biofuels and copious storage for the sequestered carbon and places a burden on generations to come for thousands of years to maintain that sequester carbon. Reversing the global warming we have already caused is completely unviable - but it is physically possible.
As it is, integrated assessment modelling (IAMs) suggests that NETs are required for any reasonable attempt at keeping below 2degC, so keeping to the Paris accord will require us to do “the reverse effect” anyway. If not - an given the current INDCs countries supplied to Paris, we are on course for a global temperature rise of ~3degC - uncomfortable close to the figure of 4C which is widely viewed as “incompatible with a global human civilisation”.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859959000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'3791246', u'in_reply_to': u'118859771', u'id': u'118860723', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'UtterTosh', u'text': u'Heatwave in Japan = good too apparently... 20,000 people admitted to hospital.... https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/24/unprecedented-japan-heatwave-kills-65-people-week', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859938000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3578538', u'in_reply_to': u'118856492', u'id': u'118860703', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bassireland', u'text': u'Your evidence for the apocalyptic 10-15-20 year timescale please. 
Otherwise you’re no better than the deniers.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859913000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2849622', u'in_reply_to': u'118860244', u'id': u'118860686', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Pullein', u'text': u'Yes, we are an extraordinary species for adapting, however, many experts have said that the earlier we start reducing our climate change impact the less it will cost us financially, economically, and in terms of food supplies and comfort. The costs of doing little and just adapting will be far higher and more likely to involve disrupted and reduced food supplies. If we are to leave it to adaptation we will probably be forced to reduce our levels of consumption, including food. My fear is that leaving it to adaptation might mean our ecosystems can only support a dramatically smaller population by the end of the century. The likely methods of reduction would be starvations and the diseases it makes us more susceptible to, and wars over dwindling resources. I hope we choose to use our brilliance to make a planned transition soon, but could we cooperate enough to do so? I hope so, I really do.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859862000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11741560', u'in_reply_to': u'118859494', u'id': u'118860642', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gavernism', u'text': u'Well the anti climate change lobby guys want us to believe that everything is hunky dory when human life itself is threatened. So yeah, if this was a movie they would be the bad guys. The good guys are most of us who can see what is happening but haven’t worked out what to do yet.
But this isn’t a movie, but reality, so has both far more possibilities for a farcical ending or something so splendid we will all congratulate ourselves when we achieve the seemingly impossible when seconds before we were facing utter destruction. We seem to be good at doing that.If there is one game that sums humanity up it is poker or 21.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859838000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4660292', u'in_reply_to': u'118858284', u'id': u'118860614', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Hughie8', u'text': u'The Guardian has already published an article about reducing the human population by half to stop the inevitable changes due upon us. Since that is not going to happen the sixth mass extinction will accelerate. I truly fear for my kids.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1532859816000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12764229', u'id': u'118860597', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'funkymentalist', u'text': u'There's more leadership on the denial side. description: Britain won’t be unscathed by global warming. You can’t run from climate change and you can’t hide
