description: Dana Nuccitelli: Like opposing civil rights and gay marriage, climate denial will drive voters away from the GOP
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Like opposing civil rights and gay marriage, climate denial will drive voters away from the GOP
og_fields.og:title: Republicans try to save their deteriorating party with another push for a carbon tax | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
The Republican Party is rotting away. The problem is that GOP policies just aren’t popular. Most Americans unsurprisingly oppose climate denial, tax cuts for the wealthy, and putting children (including toddlers) in concentration camps, for example.
The Republican Party has thus far managed to continue winning elections by creating “a coalition between racists and plutocrats,” as Paul Krugman put it. The party’s economic policies are aimed at benefitting wealthy individuals and corporations, but that’s a slim segment of the American electorate. The plutocrats can fund political campaigns, but to capture enough votes to win elections, the GOP has resorted to identity politics. Research has consistently shown that Trump won because of racial resentment among white voters.
The modern GOP is basically Steve Bannon, Steve King and Stephen Miller on one side engaged in a project to preserve and enshrine dominance for its ethnic/racial base, and Paul Ryan and John Roberts on the other who pretend they have no idea what they’re up to.
While that strategy has worked in the short-term, some Republicans recognize that it can’t work in the long-term, and they’re fighting to save their party from extinction.
Climate change is one of many issues that divides the Republican Party. Like racial resentment, climate denial is a position held mostly by old, white, male conservatives. There’s a climate change generational, ethnic, and gender gap. 61% of Republicans under the age of 50 support government climate policies, compared to just 44% of Republicans over 50. Similarly, a majority of Hispanic- and African-Americans accept human-caused global warming and 70% express concern about it, as compared to just 41% of whites who accept the scientific reality and 50% who worry about it.
But the plutocratic wing of the GOP loves fossil fuels. Republican politicians rely on campaign donations from the fossil fuel industry, and quid pro quo requires them to do the industry’s bidding. It might as well be called the Grand Oil Party. 
There is no other reason why the GOP should not unify behind a revenue-neutral carbon tax. This free market, small government climate policy – which taxes carbon pollution and returns all the revenue to American households – is indeed supported by many conservatives. A group of Republican elder statesmen created a coalition called the Climate Leadership Council to build conservative support for a revenue-neutral carbon tax. They’re now backed by Americans for Carbon Dividends (AfCD), led in part by former Republican Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott with a renewed effort to build support for this policy.
AfCD recently released polling results showing that 55% of Americans believe US environmental policy is headed in the wrong direction (29% say it’s on the right track), 81% of likely voters including 58% of Strong Republicans agree the government should take action to limit carbon emissions, and by a 56% to 26% margin (including a 55% to 32% margin among Strong Republicans), Americans support a revenue-neutral carbon tax. 
It’s not a wildly popular policy proposal, but it does have broad bipartisan support. It’s also a smart way to curb climate change with minimal economic impact, and in fact with a massive net economic benefit compared to unchecked climate change. That’s why economists overwhelmingly support a carbon tax.
The GOP was on the wrong side of history on civil rights and gay marriage and has paid the price, having largely become the party of old, straight, white men. Climate change is a similarly critical historical issue, but one that will directly impact every single American. Some smart Republicans recognize that the party can’t afford to be on the wrong side of history again on this issue.
Donald Trump managed to win the presidency in 2016 by stoking racial resentment among white Americans, but still lost the popular vote by a margin of nearly 3 million, and Republicans have only won the presidential popular vote once in the past two decades. They’re winning elections by relying on structural advantages (gerrymandering and weighting of rural votes), voter suppression, and mobilizing older white voters.
Trump seems to be doubling down on the latter strategy ahead of the 2018 midterm elections, for example by claiming that illegal immigrants are “infesting” America and by putting immigrant children in concentration camps. While only 25% of Americans support separating immigrant children from their parents, 49% of Republicans favor the policy. It’s a recipe for turning out the racist base (who also tend to be climate deniers), but not for winning a general election. Especially over the long-term as America becomes less white and as younger, more tolerant Americans become a larger proportion of the electorate.
When asked about the child concentration camps at a press conference, Senator David Perdue (R-GA) made the connection between the GOP coalition of plutocrats and racists, telling reporters: 
we came here to talk about a crisis. Your job is to inform the American people, our job is to provide solutions. ... God help us if we don’t solve this debt crisis. This is the No. 1 topic in America today … I want to make sure that the few minutes that we have didn’t get hijacked by the current shiny object of the day. [The national debt] is the current crisis in America.
The national debt might be less of a crisis had the GOP not added well over $1tn to the deficit in order to give wealthy Americans a tax cut. But apparently, it’s now a greater crisis than the American government taking immigrant children from their parents and putting them in concentration camps, or the existential threat posed by climate change. In other words, GOP priority #1 is further enriching plutocrats, priority #2 is reducing the national debt by cutting programs that help non-plutocrats; keeping families together and preserving a livable climate fall somewhere down the list.
Outside of the Republican base, these are unpopular priorities and policies. But as Katie Arrington, who recently beat Climate Solutions Caucus member Rep. Mark Sanford (R-SC) in a primary put it, “We are the party of President Donald J. Trump.” That’s a party that can only win races that are decided by white racial resentment. It’s a party that, given demographic changes, has become an endangered species. 
Some Republicans are trying to save the party by embracing smart policies like a revenue-neutral carbon tax. But so far, the party dodos are winning.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for humanity and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

September 2017. Photograph: Michael Held', u'height': u'1342'}}, {u'type': u'http://schema.org/ImageObject', u'properties': {u'url': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/e2b5008a248a47745b962b25c5ca41498942be7d/0_180_2623_1573/master/2623.jpg?width=700&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=fd0f66097ea507118e9b5d6f826c426f', u'width': u'2623', u'contentUrl': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/e2b5008a248a47745b962b25c5ca41498942be7d/0_180_2623_1573/master/2623.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=513419bbd373c7031164fea43ae0bc27', u'description': u'Main Street economies suffer when too much of the money in circulation flows to finance, without clear incentives to lend to small businesses. The steadily rising monthly carbon dividend makes sure more of the money in circulation flows through small businesses, locking in that incentive and making the whole economy more efficient at creating wealth for the average household. Photograph: Joseph Robertson', u'height': u'1573'}}, {u'type': u'http://schema.org/ImageObject', u'properties': {u'url': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/62b2c40fc46c3e93a0ae59c80bd30a7d5276272d/0_0_1446_746/master/1446.jpg?width=700&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=827922bc2ec69cf891fd3d4daa9a78b3', u'width': u'1446', u'contentUrl': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/62b2c40fc46c3e93a0ae59c80bd30a7d5276272d/0_0_1446_746/master/1446.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=10b0dee9b70bf94e0d0c4dbc4be7e4fb', u'description': u'A study by Regional Economic Models, Inc., which modeled the interacting economy-wide impacts of monthly household carbon dividends found real disposable personal income rising for at least 20 years after the first dividends show up in the mail. Details at http://CitizensClimateLobby.org/REMI-Report Illustration: Regional Economic Models, Inc.', u'height': u'746'}}, {u'type': u'http://schema.org/ImageObject', u'properties': {u'url': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a4cb9a533f2bd54c9c164206a2d77cbfbd568b30/184_0_3663_2199/master/3663.jpg?width=700&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=674559d511c5be6080cc90bf3fdf8060', u'width': u'3663', u'contentUrl': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a4cb9a533f2bd54c9c164206a2d77cbfbd568b30/184_0_3663_2199/master/3663.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=a5bfa4a7bbd0d0e354ad057f87388555', u'description': u'The steadily rising carbon dividend means farm communities can count on more reliable income from both consumers and commodities markets. As the low-carbon incentive moves through a richer marketplace, smart farmers will be positioned to capture economy-wide opportunity. Photograph: Joseph Robertson', u'height': u'2199'}}]

BQEND
Well, if you are not a denier, I apologise, genuinely.
FWIW if you use denial sites like canadafreepress.com, then it's not a big leap to conclude that you value their judgement.
It's not true to say that carbon taxes have done nothing. In the UK, we have all but eliminated coal from our electricity generation owing to setting a floor price for carbon (aka a carbon tax).
Again, I am sorry if you aren't a denier. It is fair to say - I think - that mainstream thinking on climate is in favour of a carbon tax. It's probably also true that not all manifestations have been successful, but it's too broad a statement to claim that "Carbon taxes have been a failure wherever they have been tried all around the world."', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531161378000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'118033380', u'id': u'118035110', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQSTART

BQEND
BQENDOr, more simply, why not simply accept what I said?
 I got an EV because I wanted the efficiency and environmental benefits of an EV and, as i keep telling you, because there is a great tax break on company e-cars and, tbf, all the rest is gravy.
So this year Tax is 9% compared to the 20% it would have been for my lovely old Audi.
But hey, single out congestion charge if you think it helps.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531159503000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'there is a great tax break on company e cars', u'effect': u'as i keep telling you'}, {u'cause': u'i wanted the efficiency and environmental benefits of an ev and as i keep telling you is', u'effect': u'i got an ev'}], u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'118030864', u'id': u'118033370', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART
I think the alternative b) is renewables + new nuclear + less storage.
BQENDIndeed, yes I thought that was implicit.
However there is a caveat - nuclear and storage are both capital intensive.
Whilst it is often dismissed as too expensive, I suspect that using NPP for load following (as opposed to peaking) has a place in any solution and therefore has the aspects necessary to displace the need for storage and backup infrastructure.
Whilst a NPP curtailment contract may put up costs, it saves on capital spending and O&M. Plus more thermal plant means less EFR services.
There is another factor that needs to be accounted for in the mix and this one is overnight charging of EVs and DSM both of which I suspect will significantly level out demand (I don't see V2G from EVs as anything but a minor item, (if that) -possibly FFR/EFR) That is a situation that favours a larger baseload. 
The flatter the demand curve (erosion of 'off peak') that storage relies upon for arbitrage, the greater the financial stress on storage, as has happened with the German Pumped Storage sector. This moves storage from a commercial entity to a flat overhead.
All things being equal.
... as we know, what makes economic sense and what receives the approbation of public spending/approval are not necessarily convergent.
No matter how appropriate, clean and safe, nobody ever got elected promoting nuclear power.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531041894000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'117947169', u'id': u'117952332', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'BQSTART

I did.
Your first example says that emissions rose on the taxed areas. However it does nothing to show that they would not have risen faster.
Your second example (I wonder if you actually read it ?) trashes your first example and goes on to say "When you pass a modest policy and it has a modest effect, the policy is a success. It did what it was designed to do."
Your third example is from a lunatic right-wing group. To give you an example of their thinking : "The internet news is awash with doom-and-gloom articles about the climate. Scenarios predicting ever more frequent weather events, like hurricanes, droughts, catastrophic rainfalls, and more millions of migrants from impoverished countries (often termed “refugees”), or none of the above, are all blamed squarely on “climate change” supposedly caused by the 0.04% of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere.."
Your fourth example is from a left-wing publication that objects to such taxes in principle.
Your fifth example (did you read it ?) tells us that the taxes work modestly : "The taxes contributed to a reduction in onshore emissions of only 1.5 percent and total emissions of 2.3 percent."
Your last link (did you read it ?) laments the poorly designed tax and contrasts it with other countries' success : "Apart from the incentive to use alternative energies, the Swedish Ministry has stated that in 1995 CO2 emissions were 15 % lower than they would have been with no tax reform and estimated the reduction for 2000 at 20–25 %."
You clearly assumed that I would be too lazy to look at your links.... well, my motto is always follow a denier's links because they will almost always contradict the claim made about them.
If you want to be remotely successful at this, you need to develop even a small amount of competence.
BQSTART
There is too much garbage articles out there, and very little quality.
BQENDI think we have to conclude that your own post fails this low hurdle.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531154264000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the 0.04 % of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'they will almost always contradict the claim made about them', u'effect': u"follow a denier 's links"}], u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'118023878', u'id': u'118028063', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART

there is no price advantage to buying an EV if you cannot charge it cheaply- the joy of owning an EV is being to home charge for 90% of the time and with a good tariff that means you can drive for pennies. charge it at a public charger and it is 25p kWh.
BQENDSo you're saying that a sizeable proportion of the UK population who cannot park a car on a driveway overnight to "home charge" should stick to Petrol and Diesel?
That's utter nonsense.
And who charges overnight at 25p/kwh??
You make up this nonsense as you go along.
Still waiting to hear how you think your hybrid outperforms an EV.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530949840000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'117907317', u'id': u'117917613', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'You are aware that your link is so incredibly flawed it is actually used as a point of ridicule and even has its own wikipedia section pointing out how irrationally contrived it is?https://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Benjamin_K._Sovacool#Bird_mortality_studies', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531036701000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100526028', u'in_reply_to': u'117868307', u'id': u'117949229', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I suggest you stop now - engine heat exchangers with a closed loop are not uncommon because for expensive marine engines salt water will corrode the block- and it was adapted to heat hot water in more expensive boats.This tech has been around for some time - more recent is air conditioning units that can be put into reverse for heating use the hull as a source, but these blow air.Of course canal water is fresh so the engineering of the exchange/calorifier doesn't have to be so robust.When you first mentioned it a water heat exchange unit for heating was entirely new to me- and just co-incides with a potential eco canal barge I may be involved in building where the client does not want to burn a lot of diesel . Initially I was simply going for MVHE [similar to one I converted in a live in truck], but a canal offers a huge heat sink and no need to dig up the lawn.and there are many ways to reduce canal weed clogging up the intake- given diesel and outboards do it with little issue.an off the shelf version would be ideal - but thanks for presenting a potential business idea [although it would have been very appropriate in the other river heating article]', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531153127000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'for expensive marine engines salt water will corrode the block-', u'effect': u'now engine exchangers are not uncommon'}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'118020820', u'id': u'118026607', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ColinG', u'text': u'BQSTART
Hiya. I see your point but need to point out that the alternatives don't have to cost 1-2c/kWh or less, that's not what they are competing against.
BQEND
Of course, I wasn't clear enough. In order for the market to select them, the competing technologies need to be more profitable than gas plus the cost of its carbon tax.
BQSTART
RE in the US is already closing in on gas generation, especially new gas generation, so 1-2c/kWh would probably tip the balance.

Is the likely cost of: a) Renewables+storage,more or less than the likely cost of; b) Renewables+new nuclear (the direction the UK and France et al have chosen)
BQEND
While I broadly agree, I think the alternative b) is renewables + new nuclear + less storage.
We will use some storage, but the more nuclear we have the less storage we need. Obviously nuclear avoids squandering storage on baseload; but nuclear also uses storage more efficiently for load-following because it is more predictable and less sporadic than wind.
BQSTART
plus it needs a gas backup and we have failed to develop a CCS solution for gas backup.
BQEND
To be honest, I don't think CCS would be targeted at backup. It is so capital intensive that it would primarily be for baseload.
BQSTART
The problem for (b) is the significant upfront capital cost and construction time for nuclear..
BQEND
At the risk of getting back on topic, here is the rub:
Most of the cost of nuclear is the cost of financing the capital. The actual amount of capital for the volume of output is not particularly excessive; but the length of contruction mean that the cost of capital (interest or equity returns) is the major factor which determines the price of nuclear electricity.
If we go down the route of simply setting a carbon price, and letting the market determine what the private sector will build, that is unlikely to end up with cheap nuclear. Why? Because private investors want equity returns of 10%+ on a nuclear plant.
Whereas, in times of historic low interest rates, the route to cheap nuclear is to finance via 2-3% govt bonds or similar vehicles. Of course, any other technology would benefit from low financing rates, but nuclear is uniquely sensitive to the cost of capital, and it benefits the most.
If you have something with a high capital cost, long construction time, and relatively fixed output, it is hard to make a profit from it regardless of how cheap it might be in the long term.
(The point we need to remember is that the market does not select on the basis of lowest cost for the consumer. It selects on the basis of highest return for the shareholder. Obviously if you are comparing identical technologies then lower costs go hand-in-hand with higher returns. But if you are comparing radically different technologies, with different capital profiles, that is not the case.)', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531032513000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it is more predictable and less sporadic than wind', u'effect': u'nuclear also uses storage more efficiently for load following'}], u'author_id': u'2578657', u'in_reply_to': u'117939918', u'id': u'117947169', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'you have a point about housing- although we need to build quite a few between now and 2050 and all the time standard housing is going up so energy will be wasted in the future.however the big area is commercial buildings that tend to have quite short lifetimes and who are bigger users of energy and commercially would benefit from driving down costs. lower efficiency heat pumps are commercially advanced but anything that can improve efficiency such as priming the ground with summer heat surely has some benefit. The truth is that some form of carbon tax/pollution damages is both in line with free market thinking and good for capitalism.
BQEND
I am not wholly convinced that a market-based approach to carbon will reduce emissions quickly enough though.
The market will optimise carbon emissions. That is, it will maximise emissions for minimum cost, rather than minimising emissions.
BQSTART
As Arnie Schwarzenegger pointed out in a recent facebook video that has gone viral protecting coal is like the government saving Blockbuster Video just as Netflicks was doing well- which is not about the freemarket.
BQEND
The problem is that the "Netflix" (which is killing coal's "Blockbuster" in the US) is shale gas.
It is still a high carbon emitter - it is just more profitable than coal.
The issue is that the externalities of burning gas, when converted to cash, are just not enough to influence the market very much. The externalities are around 1-2c/kWh. There are no alternatives that can do all the jobs that gas does, within that cost. So the market will never get rid of gas if it only has to cover the carbon cost.
We didn't get rid of lead in petrol by introducing a lead tax and leaving the market to sort it out. That would have taken decades if not centuries. We banned new vehicles from using leaded petrol and phased it out that way.
I'm pretty sure that is the approach we should take to reducing emissions.
Superficially a carbon tax might seem like a route to getting laissez faire capitalists on-side with climate change. But I think we're fooling ourselves if we think it would force a rapid transition away from carbon emissions.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530940160000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2578657', u'in_reply_to': u'117872891', u'id': u'117915207', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ColinG', u'text': u'BQSTART

Is the likely cost of:a) Renewables+storage,more or less than the likely cost of; b) Renewables+new nuclear (the direction the UK and France et al have chosen)
There are side points to consider of course - such as carbon footprint and grid costs but even so, if one option is greater than the other then that's a reasonable indication - at least as far as one can reasonably judge from where we are.
The problem for (a) is that expected industry prices for battery storage are $375/kwh by 2025 and you can see from there graph there isn't a great deal more that can be trimmed off that, plus it needs a gas backup and we have failed to develop a CCS solution for gas backup.
The problem for (b) is the significant upfront capital cost and construction time for nuclear.. but our best estimates are that is less than storage plus we avoid a lot of grid enhancement costs and void the necessity for a big gas standby (although we still need CCS for (a) or (b) or any mix of the two.

Your original phrase can therefore be rewritten as

Perhaps, however, this implies that industrial animal agriculture is still the #1 driver of our runaway climate change emergency ...

BQSTART
"In 2017 wind power provided 15% of the UK's total electricity.." A desperately poor result considering that deployed wind capacity is near 60% of typical demand. Thus, even with unlimited storage we'd need 140GW of wind capacity to meet typical demands. 
Even with such a vast number of windmills, the issue to be faced is that outages can still be weeks in length, and no conceivable battery can provide backup for that length of time.
This is why I say that the '100% renewables by 2050' notion is a pipedream if based on wind and solar. Numbers can be cruel, but he who ignores them is in for an unpleasant surprise.
BQEND
1. "A desperately poor result considering that deployed wind capacity is near 60% of typical demand. "Do you consider wind's contribution to be desperately poor based on nameplate capacity, or are you well informed enough not to expect the capacity factor to be 100% ? 
2. "Thus, even with unlimited storage we'd need 140GW of wind capacity to meet typical demands." I am sure that you don't think that 'unlimited storage' has anything to with with reality. Antaeus is making a purely anti-wind point with a premise so false as to be risible.
3. "Even with such a vast number of windmills, the issue to be faced is that outages can still be weeks in length, and no conceivable battery can provide backup for that length of time." Notice the use of 'windmills' - a pejorative term used by those knocking wind turbines. Again, a silly argument implying that we need battery storage (or any other type) when the wind doesn't blow. 
4. "This is why I say that the '100% renewables by 2050' notion is a pipedream if based on wind and solar." There are those who believe that 100% renewables by 2050 is possible, but they deserve a better level of discussion than this.
And shall we have a look at a few of Antaeus' contributions to give a bit of context ?
BQSTART
it's the wind turbine promoters who are engaged in short term thinking. They are creating a deliberate panic situation so that money will be thrown at their products.
BQEND

wind and solar have done nothing to reduce CO2 emissions, whereas the USA has reduced its emissions by switching to shale gas. So, who is needlessly causing climate change?

the countries with the most wind and solar deployment have actually seen an increase in fossil fuel usage.

It seems to be an important point for a lot of people. Some believe that the optimal route to decarbonisation is not 100% renewable. Others disagree.
BQENDYes that's the crucial point. I think most of us agree with the initial starting point:
RE + nuclear + storage.
For some of us, we then extract the most expensive component (nuclear) and compare it economically with the cost of RE + storage, and believe that the second option is cheaper, giving us a revised position:
RE + (RE + storage) + storage
This position is based on the current costs of RE and storage and the price reduction trends.
We can now look at nuclear's inability to reduce costs over 60yrs of subsidy support, and the opposite for RE and storage with only about 10yrs of significant support.
So nuclear gives us two gifts, a vast amount of 'approved' expenditure, and a lot of time for costs trends to continue to reduce RE/storage costs, since deployments are simpler, faster and also in some cases retrospective (as in batts being added to wind and solar sites).
We can even compare individual projects, such as HPC, which at a 35yr cost of £100/MWh v's the NAO estimated wholesale price of £50, will suck up £44bn in subsidies.
Off-shore wind at the 2023 allocation price could deliver that amount of generation for £5bn (and off-shore costs haven't stopped falling) gifting us £39bn in spare subsidy monies over 35yrs to steadily invest in storage or more generating capacity.
PV and on-shore wind are now starting to go subsidy free in some locations/situations and costs will continue to fall, and could even go sub £20/MWh by 2050.
BQSTART
For the solar industry in particular, BNEF is predicting a 17-fold increase in capacity globally and the levelised cost of electricity (LCoE) will fall a further 71% by 2050, having already fallen by 77% between 2009 and 2018. The wind industry will benefit from a sixfold increase in capacity and see its own LCoE fall a further 58%, from the 41% decrease seen over the previous decade.
BQEND
The US, the largest nuclear generation has all but turned their backs on nuclear. They only had 4 reactors under construction, and two were halted mid build recently as they won't be economic on completion. All they have to do is show you a poor immigrant, and all your political energy turns to them. Look- if the increase of the wealth of the top 0.01 elite was so terrific for Americans generally, then the wealth of all Americans wpuld have increased by the same proportion. Not amount, just proportion. But it hasn't- the wealth of the top has skyrocketed (largely because of changes in finance laws in the '70's and '80's), whilst the rest have more or less stagnated. The top few own three times more of America now than forty years ago. Was America forty years ago Socialist? No. Its just that the financial elite hadn't yet convinced people like yourself that increasing the wealth of this elite was the sole purpose of the US economy.Face it dude, you've all been mugged. If that makes you proud, then I'm happy for you.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530865057000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"changes in finance laws in the 's", u'effect': u'the wealth of the top has skyrocketed whilst the rest have more or less stagnated'}], u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'117858687', u'id': u'117872567', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'Kenny loves his hunting- so what's wrong with high tech bird hunters?', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530900579000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'117900839', u'id': u'117901221', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Joseph Robertson: A carbon tax and dividend system could usher in an era of clean energy independence
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Joseph Robertson: A carbon tax and dividend system could usher in an era of clean energy independence
og_fields.og:title: Declare energy independence with carbon dividends | Joseph Robertson
text:
Taking action on climate is about a lot more than our energy economy. Climate disruption is the leading threat to our built environment, an accelerant of armed conflict, and a leading cause of mass migration. Its effects intensify and prolong storms, droughts, wildfires, and floods — resulting in the US spending as much on disaster management in 2017 as in the three decades from 1980 to 2010.
Fiscal conservatism and national security require a smart, focused, effective solution that protects our economy and our values.
Political division between the major parties in Washington has left the burden of achieving that solution largely on Democratic administrations using regulatory measures that — for all their smart design and ambition — cannot be transformational enough to carry us through to a livable future.
Conservatives say the nation needs an insurance policy. Business leaders want to future-proof their operations and investments. Young people are demanding intervention on the scale of the Allies’ efforts to rebuild Europe after World War II. 
The International Monetary Fund — whose mission is to ensure national dysfunction doesn’t undermine the solvency of public budgets and lead to failed states — warns that nations that depend heavily on publicly subsidized fossil fuels are endangering their future solvency by investing in a way that destroys future economic resilience. Resilience intelligence requires diversification and innovation on a massive scale. 
The rapid expansion of green bonds is making clear the deep need for clean economy holdings among major banks and institutional investors. Climate-smart finance, still a new concept, is expected to be the standard for both public and private-sector actors at all levels within 10 to 20 years. 
Republican former Secretaries of the Treasury James Baker and George Shultz have called for a carbon dividends strategy, because: 
Unpaid-for pollution and climate disruption limit our personal freedom and then, by adding cost and risk to the whole economy, undermine our collective ability to defend our freedom and secure future prosperity. Even with record oil and gas production, the US still depends heavily on foreign regimes hostile to democracy that manipulate supply and undermine the efficiency of our everyday economy. 
Energy freedom means reliable, everywhere-active low-cost clean energy, answering the call of expanded Main Street economic activity.
Ask any small business owner if they would rather have higher or lower hidden business costs built into everything they buy from their suppliers. Of course, they would prefer lower hidden costs and risks, and for consumers to have more money in their pockets. 
That is how carbon dividends work. 
The result is a steady shift in new investment to practices that are more competitive on a level playing field. With the flow of dividend dollars through local economies, lawmakers can concretely leverage good policy to motivate new investment and job creation, without having to build “bridges to nowhere.”
Banks will either lead or follow, but it is certain that when investment in local economies and energy innovation are both more efficient than they are now, finance at all levels will go to work on that trend. Trillions of dollars in subsidies for the old economy will be freed up to support expansion of the new economy.
New opportunities for industrial production of clean energy devices, electric vehicle infrastructure, battery storage, smart grids and related services, will ensure under-served communities in both rural and urban areas will draw new investment and locally rooted job creation.
There is no faster way to reduce emissions while driving investment into the creation of millions of new jobs. There is no more economically efficient way to ensure the 21st century energy innovation economy reaches major cities, heavy industry, and also “the last mile,” where conventional infrastructure has always been hardest to fund. 
The shortest route to American energy freedom and climate solvency is through a clear-headed, high-efficiency carbon dividends strategy. 
Joseph Robertson is Global Strategy Director for Citizens’ Climate Lobby, Founder and President of the Geoversiv Foundation, and lead strategist in the Resilience Intel initiative.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

Wheat came from all over the place - Turkey, Iraq, Israel, and lost of Central Asia.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531059977000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117957869', u'id': u'117961761', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Fogmaker', u'text': u'Who are you speaking for?
The so called revolution was always about imposing stricter religious (Sunni) law - those were the people who were armed. Their well funded Media Centers was used to recruit young people and trying to create Sectarian strife, which ultimately backfired.
There are not many Christians left in the Middle East. People from Iraq used to go to Syria on Holidays.
As you noted, many Syrian Christians left the country long before the War, but most retained a connection to the homeland (building houses, many of which are now destroyed, for retirement etc)
Hezbollah initially entered the war to defend the border areas and nearby (Shia) villages. But as the conflict went on, it’s became a security threat to Lebanon as well (as I wrote somewhere else years ago, if the Syrian Government falls, so will Lebanon). If the the US, the Gulf States, Turkey etc had stopped the funding of this war, they would have returned home a long time ago.
There’s been intense talks and negotiations lately and peace is finally in sight, see the South of the Country and the continuing work to disarm even pro Government militias (as a note, several of these militias are actually Sunni)
To find a political solution will continue to be very difficult, but not impossible.
Hopefully it will remain a pluralistic society.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531056127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16201117', u'in_reply_to': u'117933027', u'id': u'117960033', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'anon-3a11b71136524b', u'text': u'The Syrian government are mostly Alawites, not sure how well this will go down in the rest of the Middle East if Syria benefits in any way.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531052222000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17661015', u'id': u'117958184', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'awesomeants', u'text': u'Considering pretty much all our wheat originates from there I'm fair sure they are', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531051518000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12375233', u'in_reply_to': u'117955442', u'id': u'117957869', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Felipe1st', u'text': u'No problem so long as the subsequent enrichment is shared with country of origin and not simply stuffed into the pockets of the few.
Eliminating the competitive element so enjoyed by crapitalist extremists could be one way to secure cooperation between nations.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531050750000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4441698', u'in_reply_to': u'117931823', u'id': u'117957505', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Felipe1st', u'text': u'Thanks for the heads-up explanation.
So-called first world enrichment tactics again and I would expect the same from big pharma and it's treatment of rain forest discoveries.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531050592000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4441698', u'in_reply_to': u'117955605', u'id': u'117957428', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'The US already had these very seeds - they came from Kyoto University in Japan from their collectors in Azerbaijan. Millions of seed samples have been collected and moved around the world over more than a century. It is (or at least was - the system has gone belly-up) totally normal. We all benefit. Seventy percent of food grown in Latin America and Africa comes from originally imported seed. It is more than than for the UK, Canada, The USA, Australia and lots more developed countries.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531049408000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117878470', u'id': u'117956805', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'How many times do you need telling - the sample came from Azerbaijan and certainly not Syria. It is a journalistic error.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531048885000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117887189', u'id': u'117956508', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'One third of the bread you may eat every day comes from this `hearty wheat' (the D-genome of the hexaploid wheat's ABD genetics): who do you want to pay for it?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531048747000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117897498', u'id': u'117956430', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'Good point - but more to the point is that Ae. tauschii is the D-genome in hexaploid wheat - the stuff that we make bread from and eat probably every day. The hexaploid originated from a natural cross - recognized as a good thing by farmers thousands of years ago. Described by Harlan:"Some time during the neolithic of the Near East, the genomes of tetraploid wheatcombined with that of Aegilops squarrosa [now = Ae. tauschii]. This little weedy goatgrass is the only member of the genus with a continental distribution and the only one extending into the Central Asian steppes. It transformed a rather ordinary cereal into the most widely grown food crop on earth."It is fatuous to argue about who we pay for this (and if payment is to be made for anything it goes to the UN FAO in Rome as a tax on seed use).', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531048540000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117901863', u'id': u'117956333', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'The US and many other countries have huge collections of traditional varieties of crops from all over the world. India, Brasil, China. Russia and lots more each have 100,000+ samples in cold stores.These samples are the raw material for lots of plant breeding. It started well over a century ago with no problems until the FAO Seed Treaty kicked in. Now most developing countries are hanging on to their seed: dog in the manger as samples are more use outside - but you can't blame them.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531047772000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117881321', u'id': u'117955899', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'If there are any royalties to be paid they will go to the UN FAO (in Rome) and not Syria. The FAO Seed Treaty does not recognize `country of origin' of samples. But the sample used was collected long before the Treaty existed so there probably will be no payment to anywhere.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531047233000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117901573', u'id': u'117955605', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'The seeds are not from Syria.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531046958000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'in_reply_to': u'117886109', u'id': u'117955442', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/07/donald-trump-ban-all-muslims-entering-us-san-bernardino-shooting', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531041401000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'117931786', u'id': u'117952007', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldmoss', u'text': u'The article is bad reporting. The Hessian-fly resistance comes from the sample KU2147, a Aegilops tauschii accession collected from Azerbaijan by Kihara and others in the 1960s - nothing to do with ICARDA or Syria. I have had this confirmed by the head of the institute actually doing the work in the USA. As is usual with seed samples, the original sample from Kyoto University (KU) was duplicated all over the place before there were Treaties to control seed movement.Now anyone using a seed sample covered by the FAO Seed Treaty will be expected - if varieties are bred using the sample and also then only if the new variety is patented - to pay a tax to FAO (a UN organization). Azerbaijan and other countries-of-origin get nothing. The biggest disgrace of the Seed Treaty is that non-member counties have totally lost control of previously distributed seed. For example, Mexico, with probably 200,000 samples covered by the Treaty and now stored away from Mexico can do nothing whatever to benefit from or restrict the patenting of derivatives of seed that was once a national heritage. Naturally Mexico has stopped distributing samples. This UN Treaty-caused lock-down is a disaster for future global food production. Investigative journalists are not interested.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531033337000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3615546', u'id': u'117947504', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesValencia', u'text': u'Very interesting, thanks.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531006990000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3761271', u'id': u'117942803', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rebel7', u'text': u'"preferable to jihadi rule"
Syrian revolution didn't start out seeking jihadi rule. The revolution was mostly usurped by the jihadi's. Just as the Russian Revolution, Iranian Revolution were both usurped by movements that didn't start the fight. 
I've yet to meet a Syrian who actually likes Assad and his gang of thieves. Its entirely comparative. Given ISIS or Assad-they prefer Assad by a large margin. Given Assad's version of the Baath Party and genuine representative government-they prefer representative government.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530985782000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13612545', u'in_reply_to': u'117912559', u'id': u'117933027', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rebel7', u'text': u'"Why isn’t he home fighting, protecting his/her homeland from foreign invasion?"
Iranians, Russians, AND Lebanese Hezbullah are all foreigners. There at the invitation of the Syrian government. So he'd be one of the rebels.
Many of the Syrians currently in the US, Canada, Sweden, et al are Christians who left Syria on account of oppressive conditions created by the Sunni Muslim majority population of the country.
https://sputniknews.com/viral/201806251065751566-sweden-football-racism/
Now the war is over: locals are reporting that in some districts the Christians and Alawites who stayed when the Sunni residents fled to Lebanon and elsewhere are resisting the attempts of the Sunnis to return.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530984498000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13612545', u'in_reply_to': u'117925918', u'id': u'117932181', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rebel7', u'text': u'Paris Climate Accord is a joke. F--- the accord!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530983961000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13612545', u'in_reply_to': u'117911553', u'id': u'117931856', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rebel7', u'text': u'"US gene patent lawyers will seek to extract"
Why not?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530983919000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13612545', u'in_reply_to': u'117915447', u'id': u'117931823', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rebel7', u'text': u'"a Mid East whose citizens are deprived of succor in our land, turned away at every gateway with racist and religious intent"
The travel ban doesn't include Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, none of the Gulf Emirates. Its Syria and Yemen.
So if it was both racists and religious-why is still possible for citizens of those nations to travel to the US?
A Syrian travel ban is perfectly sensible. Because Syrian official records are crap, at best. How are we supposed to know that Ahmed is Ahmed?
It works like this: My wife was born in Syria. As were all of her brothers and sisters. The family registered the births with the local Church. Then they registered with the government. So happens the government clerks tended to be almost entirely Sunni Muslim, who inconveniently for you tend to harbor long-standing bias against Christians. So not ONE of those family members births were officially recorded consistent with how they were recorded at the Church. Christian family shows up with baby Nuri born July 25, 1962 and the clerk records it as "Ali" born April 2, 1960.

description: Ancient Syrian grass rescued from Aleppo is resistant to pests devastating American farms This article was originally published by the Yale school of forestry
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Ancient Syrian grass rescued from Aleppo is resistant to pests devastating American farms This article was originally published by the Yale school of forestry
og_fields.og:title: Syrian seeds could save US wheat from climate menace
text:
Inside a Kansas greenhouse, a buzzing horde of flies set about laying waste to 20,000 seedlings. But as researchers watched, there was one species of growth that remained untouched – an ancient Syrian grass known as Aegilops tauschii.
Now those Syrian seeds, once stored in a vault outside of Aleppo, could end up saving US wheat from the menaces of climate change.
From 2000 to 2015, average temperatures in the US midwest rose from 1 to 2 degrees fahrenheit above the 20th-century average. Periods of time between rainfalls are lengthening, according to a 2016 assessment by the Environmental Protection Agency. In other words, conditions in some areas of the midwest are starting to resemble conditions in the Middle East. 
Rising temperatures are already leading to drops in midwestern crop yields, and threaten further reductions of as much as 4% per year. In the heart of US cereal and grain country, new pests and diseases are following the hot and dry conditions northward – and frequently overwhelming the ability of agricultural chemicals to battle them off. In response, scientists are seeking sources of natural resistance – and finding them in Syria, in the heart of the Fertile Crescent, the birthplace of domesticated agriculture.
One of the world’s most important seed banks used to be located about 25 miles west of Aleppo in the town of Tal Hadya, and was run by the International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas (Icarda). That UN-affiliated centre specialises in preserving and researching seeds in hot, dry areas – conditions now being faced by many of the Earth’s food-growing regions.
It’s also the place of origin of today’s domesticated wheat, and the seeds that were stored there benefit from genes embedded with survival strategies evolved over thousands of years. Now diseases and pests such as the Hessian fly, long familiar to Middle and Near Eastern farmers, are moving north from the southern US and Mexico and surging across Kansas and surrounding states – Oklahoma, Texas, Colorado and Nebraska and in some instances up to Illinois and the Dakotas.
Even as forces supporting the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, were bombing Aleppo in spring 2016, researchers at Kansas State University (KSU) were receiving increasingly urgent reports from US wheat farmers of devastating attacks by the Hessian fly, leading to an average 10% yield loss per year, according to the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Applied Wheat Genomics at KSU. That’s a significant bite out of the earnings of farms already operating on shaky margins.
Ming-Shun Chen, a professor of molecular entomology at KSU, says the flies’ larvae used to be killed off by the cold of winter. But that cold is coming later in the season, and the larvae survive to turn into flies. Their devouring of wheat seems drawn from science fiction: the flies don’t have teeth, so they inject a protein-based substance into the plant that transforms it into a kind of nutritious slurry they can suck up and digest. 
From November through April, Chen collaborated with the plant scientist Jesse Poland to run a sequence of experiments that unfolded in the university’s greenhouses with brutal Darwinian efficiency: they planted commercial US wheat seedlings from Kansas and surrounding states along with an assortment of wild wheat-related grasses obtained from the seed vault in Syria, as well as random other assorted plantings. The seedlings grew for two to three weeks, and then the flies were unleashed to attack. The results were clear: Syria’s Aegilops tauschii was the sole survivor.
Ever wondered why you feel so gloomy about the world - even at a time when humanity has never been this healthy and prosperous? Could it be because news is almost always grim, focusing on confrontation, disaster, antagonism and blame?
This series is an antidote, an attempt to show that there is plenty of hope, as our journalists scour the planet looking for pioneers, trailblazers, best practice, unsung heroes, ideas that work, ideas that might and innovations whose time might have come.
Readers can recommend other projects, people and progress that we should report on by contacting us at theupside@theguardian.com
Wheat has the most complex genome of any of the world’s major crops, one of the reasons efforts to genetically engineer wheat traits have thus far not succeeded. It also means it has multiple genetic “wild relatives”.
Over time the domesticated wheat, dependent on agrichemical boosters, lost resistance to diseases and pests. So breeders are reaching deep into the history of wheat to bring back some of those lost characteristics.
“Wild relatives are by definition hardier. They’ve survived on the margins of our pampering,” says Maywa Montenegro, a PhD in environmental science, policy and management at the University of California, Berkeley, who has spent years studying wild relatives of crops. “On a farm, the farmer does everything to favour his crops: he pulls out competitor plants, weeds, gives water. But the wild relatives haven’t been getting assistance for thousands of years. They’re dealing with drought and flooding and salt.” 
She said indigenous farmers have for millennia encouraged wild species to grow along the edges of their farms in order to encourage interbreeding between the wild and domesticated species to confer those strengths – a practice that has been long-neglected on massive industrial farms.
The indomitable Aegilops tauschii grows wild in Syria in the hills surrounding Tal Hadya and Aleppo. Poland cites a litany of diseases to which the grass is resistant, with names like a lineup of underground rock bands: barley yellow dwarf, mosaic virus, wheat rust. It also shows resistance traits to more than half a dozen common insect pests, including the Hessian fly. 
The tauschii and thousands of other seed varieties once stored at Icarda’s Tal Hadya seed bank have a dramatic recent history, intertwined with the Syrian civil war. The area around Aleppo was a rebel stronghold until 2016. The rebel commander in Tal Hadya, according to one of the veteran scientists who used to work at the Icarda facility, was himself a farmer and understood the importance of the seed bank.
The scientists and the rebels struck a deal: the rebels protected the seed bank and, equally important, ensured that the generator kept running to keep the stored seeds cool – in return for the scientists providing the rebels with food grown from the centre’s experimental fields. That lasted until spring 2016, when Assad’s military started bombarding Aleppo and the surrounding towns, including Tal Hadya. The remaining scientists loaded up the seeds in a truck and raced across the Lebanese frontier.
Other seeds emanating from Syria are helping farmers contend with climatic changes elsewhere in the midwest. In Illinois and the Dakotas, Syrian seeds seem to perform strongly when faced with the combination of increasing temperatures with brief but intense rainfalls, which leads to the spread of virulent fungus. Efforts are under way at the University of North Dakota, Bismarck, to introduce Syrian seeds into the breeding stock.
Poland says the latest round of Hessian fly experiments, completed in early April, affirmed KSU’s plan to incorporate the tough survivors of the fly onslaught into the breeding of commercial American wheat varieties. After undergoing formal certification and government approval, the Aegilops tauschii will be dispersed to US breeders to make their way into the besieged fields of the midwest.
The US has been losing diversity at an alarming rate during more than three decades of consolidation in the seed industry, and the steadily expanding size of farms. Diversity in seed varieties has dropped in almost every region of the country, most dramatically in the lower midwest. Globally, the UN has declared that three-quarters of all the world’s crop varieties that were around in the early 1900s had become extinct by 2015. 
“You may be using wild crop relatives to boost industrial agriculture, while industrial agriculture itself is one of the greatest pressures on their existence,” says Montenegro. “They’re threatened from the usual pressures – pollution, land-cover changes – but also from turning diverse fields into monoculture plantations.”
… we have a small favour to ask. More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

description: Donald Trump announces Pruitt’s departure on Twitter and praises him for doing an ‘outstanding job’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Donald Trump announces Pruitt’s departure on Twitter and praises him for doing an ‘outstanding job’
og_fields.og:title: Scott Pruitt, Trump's embattled EPA chief, resigns amid ethics scandals
text:
Scott Pruitt, the hugely controversial administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has resigned.
Donald Trump announced Pruitt’s departure on Twitter and said Pruitt had done an “outstanding job”. He further posted that Pruitt’s deputy Andrew Wheeler would take over as acting administrator from Monday.
...on Monday assume duties as the acting Administrator of the EPA. I have no doubt that Andy will continue on with our great and lasting EPA agenda. We have made tremendous progress and the future of the EPA is very bright!
Trump had repeatedly defended Pruitt following a multitude of ethics scandals.
In his resignation letter, Pruitt struck an unapologetic tone.
“It is extremely difficult for me to cease serving you in this role,” Pruitt wrote. “However, the unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family, are unprecedented and have taken a sizable toll on all of us.”
 Pruitt also infused several references to God while lavishing praise on the president.
“I believe you are serving as president today because of God’s providence,” he wrote. “I believe that same providence brought me into your service.”
Pruitt, a former attorney general of Oklahoma, had come under increasing pressure over issues including the use of public funds for travel and office improvements; for using an obscure provision of the Safe Drinking Water Act to give pay raises to two aides; and for having paid $50 a night to rent a room in a Capitol Hill townhouse from the wife of an energy industry lobbyist.
An EPA ethics official who initially said the condo deal was not inappropriate subsequently rowed back on that claim.
In April, Reuters cited an anonymous Republican aide who said the condo deal was being examined by the House oversight committee. The Associated Press detailed extensive spending on a “a 20-member full-time security detail” for Pruitt.
In recent weeks, the barrage of headlines over Pruitt’s alleged impropriety at the EPA escalated – prompting several staff members to resign.
A whistleblower revealed earlier this week that Pruitt kept a secret calendar to hide meetings with industry representatives. Staffers reportedly met in Pruitt’s office to alter or remove records of the meetings. It also emerged that Pruitt asked staffers to use their personal credit cards for his hotel bookings.
As of last month, Pruitt’s activities were the subject of at least 14 separate federal investigations.
Trump nonetheless continued to defend Pruitt following his resignation, telling reporters aboard Air Force One: “Scott Pruitt did an outstanding job inside of the EPA.”
“You know, obviously the controversies with Scott, but within the agency we were extremely happy,” he added.
Trump also said there was “no final straw” leading up to Pruitt’s departures and that the embattled EPA chief offered his own resignation.
“I think Scott felt that he was a distraction,” Trump said. “It was very much up to him.”
Even some Republicans, who had grown tired of defending Pruitt’s daily controversies, celebrated the news of his departure.
“Finally. Actually he did a horrible job,” Carlos Curbelo, a moderate Republican congressman from Florida, tweeted in response to Trump.
“He was a disaster and an embarrassment from day one, and the country is far better off without him.”
It was reported in April that the White House chief of staff, John Kelly, had urged Pruitt’s firing but was rebuffed by the president. 
Pruitt reportedly hoped to replace Jeff Sessions as attorney general if that job became vacant. 
He was an aggressive champion of Trump’s anti-regulation agenda, repealing a host of environmental protection measures, many implemented by the Obama administration.
“You know, I just left coal and energy country,” Trump said after a recent trip to West Virginia. “They feel very strongly about Scott Pruitt. And they love Scott Pruitt.”
Speaking to the Guardian before Pruitt resigned, a senior EPA official who asked not to be named said of agency management: “People are so done with these folks. We wanted and waited for some adults to show up. But the relentless tide of bullshit from Pruitt and his cronies is tough to deal with.”
Janet McCabe, a former EPA assistant administrator, said: “I think morale at the EPA is at a very low ebb. The bigger concern is the environmental mission of the agency. Substantively, what has happened in the last year is a big a threat as the agency has ever faced.”

… in the fight to protect the environment. By keeping the Guardian’s environmental coverage open and accessible, we can report on the changes needed to avoid climate and natural catastrophe. The choices made by individuals are important, but we need to work together for the systemic transformation that will make a real difference. As well as reporting the facts about what is happening now, we investigate the causes and talk to the people trying to make the future better. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.

article_tags: [World news, Oceans, Environment, Farming, Climate change, Climate change]
description: This week’s Upside looks at the energy potential of our oceans and a coding academy in Gaza
headline: m
og_fields.og:description: This week’s Upside looks at the energy potential of our oceans and a coding academy in Gaza
og_fields.og:title: The moon also rises – as a solution to our energy crisis
text:
We’re unlikely to find fixes to our global problems if we’re battling against our planet’s natural resources rather than making use of them. This week, some tales of harnessing the power of nature as we tackle man-made crises: climate change and our insatiable need for energy.
Move aside, the sun – could the moon be the solution to our clean energy crisis? The power of our ocean tides, the only renewable source derived from the moon, might be able to provide huge amounts of clean, renewable electricity. Damian Carrington reports from France on the extraordinary inventions that could help to harness it.
In the meantime, the sun’s not doing a bad job: a heatwave in the UK helped break solar power-generation records, with solar briefly eclipsing gas power stations as the top source of electricity. 
Rising temperatures and dry spells in the US midwest are wreaking havoc with crop yields, as new pests and diseases emerge due to hot and arid conditions. But now an ancient Syrian grass that survived a civil war might provide salvation for stricken American farmers, as Mark Schapiro explains.
Elsewhere this week, we are celebrating the 70th birthday of the UK’s National Health Service, the world’s largest government-funded healthcare system. Haroon Siddique brings us five fascinating innovations from health services around the world that could help the NHS to break new ground over the next 70 years.
And in Gaza City, Oliver Holmes and Hazem Balousha report on the strip’s first ever coding academy, where 16 students (half male, half female), surrounded by boundaries, are breaking free online. 
 This New Yorker examination of universal basic income and this Wired tale of the French boat that’s circling the planet powered by renewables. 
All these tidal sources are important and may contribute, but the main and cheapest contribution comes from efficient use. In other words: it is not sustainable to fly to remote destinations to board a ship that is supposedly cruising to important places that we must see. It is not sustainable to board a jet plane to watch a football match. And it is not sustainable to fly in food from faraway places out of season by airplane just for the kick of strawberries in winter or lamb from down under. 
Commenter, continental cyclist, writing below the line of our piece on tidal power.
In living rooms up and down Britain, where Christian Sinabaldi, Erica Buist and Deborah Linton captured the agony, ecstasy and weird snacks that friends and families from countries competing at the World Cup shared as they watched their heroes on TV.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

Many of us are doing what we can to try and help towards reducing climate change.
Clearly we need more regulation to stop huge profit making companies from producing huge levels of waste. For example there should be regulations that stop corporations from using excessive packaging.
A few other thoughts.
There should also be nothing from stopping us planning our towns and cities in better ways. We could for example plan them in such a way where vast amounts of more trees are placed in our urban areas. For many of our local highstreets there is not a single plant in sight other than a few hanging baskets hanging on the outside of shops. There would be more than enough room to plant trees in the high-street if they were planned better and had pedestrianised areas.
We could also change planning regulations to ensure that gardens are fitted on roof tops for new builds.
We could do things like develop dynamos that are fitted to fans and then have them fitted to all satellite dishes and aerial's so that they spin when the wind is blowing. This kind of technology existed 40 years ago to allow cyclists to power lights from their wheels. Even if they were only small fans that only produced a small amount of energy. If there were billions of them all over the world it would end up producing a significant amount of energy as every little helps.
We could design taps and toilets with the same kinds of fans in so that they spin when we are taking water from the supply. We could design drain pipes with the same kinds of fans.
Any product that has a spinning part could be designed to harvest energy from the spinning part while it is doing the job that it is needed to do. For example washing machines, computers, tumble driers, DVD players and the like all have spinning parts. I freely admit I do not know about the technical side of this last suggestion but surely it can't be beyond the wit of man to design products in a way where the products themselves harvest energy from a spinning part and then store that energy to make them more energy efficient. Think now of Tony Blair singing "Things can only get better". etc', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530893642000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1351539', u'id': u'117896092', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'feliciafarrel', u'text': u'BQSTART
Why do you only pick on population? What about the number of people who eat more meat than required (a big cause of habitat destruction too), or those who use cars as a convenience rather than a necessity, or watering the back garden with a hosepipe, or buying tonnes of shit we don't need. There's a lot we could all do that doesn't require culling the population.
BQEND
That's an argument I often see. The short answer is that there are many ways to ameliorate the situation but the huge underlying issue (of over population) remains and is causing stresses and massive problems which come to light on a daily basis and which means that there are more problems we can't yet see in the pipeline. 
We are very good at taking the 'hard' decisions in relation to other species. Take deer here in Scotland for instance. There are many ways to do the equivalent of not using cars, not eating meat and not using hose pipes to mitigate the effects of an exploding deer population. We could for instance build more deer fences, protect individual trees and plants, spray vegetation with a deer repellent, grow trees deer don't like to eat, stop growing trees at all! All of those would help to reduce deer damage but none of them would address the other issues that arise like starvation, and diseases relating to inbreeding and corralling. So we take steps to reduce their numbers recognising that the underlying problem is that there are simply too many deer. 
Yes, we can do the things you suggest, but those are just excuses (and worse may delay) for not tackling the real issue. Nothing can get away from the fact that our sheer numbers, never mind what we consume or what we eat, just our numbers are pushing out and killing other species. And, as Monbiot has said, species extinction is now a more serious threat to us even than climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530893616000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u"stresses and massive problems which come to light on a daily basis and which means that there are more problems we ca n't yet see in the pipeline"}], u'author_id': u'13675666', u'in_reply_to': u'117895303', u'id': u'117896071', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dercius', u'text': u'Um, however, oddly enough a result of global warming could well be a sudden I've ageThe global convection current relies on a steady stream of cold water from the poles being warmed and cycled by the gulf steam In a kind of "global heat pump"... 
If enough fresh water gets into the oceans? That's a giant problem, since salt water is denser than fresh water? Then you'll end to with a layer of cold water sitting atop the warmer salt water where it can't rise to the surface 
That could drop global temps as much as 10 degrees, which is enough to kick off a true ice age 
So don't be reaching for the sunblock just yet', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530893605000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17765662', u'in_reply_to': u'117893777', u'id': u'117896061', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tim1960', u'text': u'BQSTART

I live in Cornnarwhal.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530893520000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1940026', u'in_reply_to': u'117893784', u'id': u'117895986', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'janey smit', u'text': u'but the british isles tend to be cooler and have more rain more often. so this is unusual.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530893520000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18507475', u'in_reply_to': u'117891445', u'id': u'117895983', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Bremner', u'text': u'What biotech is meant here? It needs to to be in place very soon. Arctic ferns have (in former warm eras) fixed atmospheric CO2 and carried it to the ocean floor - according to Peter Ward’s “Under a Green Sky.” But we’re courting climate catastrophe to wait until the Arctic is warm enough. Can microorganisms be bioengineered to fix greenhouse gases and carry them to the ocean bed? But how could bioengineered microorganisms be released both safely and in sufficient numbers to impact the world climate?
